A person, who can only read but cannot write, is not literate.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Source: Census, Registrar General of India, Ministry of Home Affairs, India

wb:indicator.wb:name: Literacy Rate Male (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of male population age 7 and above who can read and write. For the purposes of census a person aged seven and above, who can both read and write with understanding in any language, is treated as literate. A person, who can only read but cannot write, is not literate.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Source: Census, Registrar General of India, Ministry of Home Affairs, India

wb:indicator.wb:name: Literacy Rate (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of population age 7 and above who can read and write. For the purposes of census a person aged seven and above, who can both read and write with understanding in any language, is treated as literate. A person, who can only read but cannot write, is not literate.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Source: Census, Registrar General of India, Ministry of Home Affairs, India

wb:indicator.wb:name: Latrine not available within premises
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Distribution of households by type of latrine facility - not available within premises
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Source: Databook for DCH December 2013 (Page 330 of 333) - Planning Commission, GOI

wb:indicator.wb:name: Latrine facility available within premises
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Distribution of households by type of latrine facility - available within premises
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Source: Databook for DCH December 2013 (Page 330 of 333) - Planning Commission, GOI

wb:indicator.wb:name: National Highways (surfaced length) - Below standard single lane (KMs)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: National Highways: Arterial roads of the country for inter-state and strategic defense movements. Surfaced Road: : A road with a hard smooth surface of bitumen or tar.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Source: Transport Research Wing, Ministry of Road Transport and Highways Table21.5-LENGTH OF NATIONAL AND STATE HIGHWAYS-BY WIDTH Http://mospi.nic.in/mospi_new/upload/SYB2014/CH-21-ROADS/Table 21.5.xls

wb:indicator.wb:name: National Highways (surfaced length) - Standard double lane (KMs)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: National Highways: Arterial roads of the country for inter-state and strategic defense movements. Surfaced Road: : A road with a hard smooth surface of bitumen or tar.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Source: Transport Research Wing, Ministry of Road Transport and Highways Table21.5-LENGTH OF NATIONAL AND STATE HIGHWAYS-BY WIDTH Http://mospi.nic.in/mospi_new/upload/SYB2014/CH-21-ROADS/Table 21.5.xls

wb:indicator.wb:name: National Highways (surfaced length) - Standard multi lane (KMs)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: National Highways: Arterial roads of the country for inter-state and strategic defense movements. Surfaced Road: : A road with a hard smooth surface of bitumen or tar.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Source: Transport Research Wing, Ministry of Road Transport and Highways Table21.5-LENGTH OF NATIONAL AND STATE HIGHWAYS-BY WIDTH Http://mospi.nic.in/mospi_new/upload/SYB2014/CH-21-ROADS/Table 21.5.xls

wb:indicator.wb:name: National Highways (surfaced length) - Standard single lane (KMs)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: National Highways: Arterial roads of the country for inter-state and strategic defense movements. Surfaced Road: : A road with a hard smooth surface of bitumen or tar.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Source: Transport Research Wing, Ministry of Road Transport and Highways Table21.5-LENGTH OF NATIONAL AND STATE HIGHWAYS-BY WIDTH Http://mospi.nic.in/mospi_new/upload/SYB2014/CH-21-ROADS/Table 21.5.xls

wb:indicator.wb:name: National Highways (surfaced length) - Total (KMs)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: National Highways: Arterial roads of the country for inter-state and strategic defense movements. Surfaced Road: : A road with a hard smooth surface of bitumen or tar.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Source: Transport Research Wing, Ministry of Road Transport and Highways Table21.5-LENGTH OF NATIONAL AND STATE HIGHWAYS-BY WIDTH Http://mospi.nic.in/mospi_new/upload/SYB2014/CH-21-ROADS/Table 21.5.xls

wb:indicator.wb:name: Urban Roads (KMs)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Length of Urban Roads (in KMs)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Source: Transport and Research Wing, Ministry of Road Transport and Highways, India Road Transport : Table 1B.3 : Statewise Rural Road Density Per 1000 Population http://mospi.nic.in/Mospi_New/upload/Infra_stat_2010/1.ch_road.pdf

wb:indicator.wb:name: Urban Roads Surfaced (KMs)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Length of Surfaced Urban Roads (in KMs)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Source: Transport and Research Wing, Ministry of Road Transport and Highways, India Road Transport : Table 1B.5 : Statewise Rural Road Density Per 1000 Population http://mospi.nic.in/Mospi_New/upload/Infra_stat_2010/1.ch_road.pdf

wb:indicator.wb:name: Number of seriously injured in road traffic crashes
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Number of seriously injured in road traffic crashes
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Source: Ministry of Road Transport and Highways (2011)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Number of road crashes
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Number of road crashes
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Source: Ministry of Road Transport and Highways (2011)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Rural Road Density (KMs/1000 Population)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Rural roads density is measured in KMs of rural roads in the area (State, District) divided by population in thousands in that area (State, District) Rural roads are roads within a district for which the specifications are lower than for district roads.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Source: Transport and Research Wing, Ministry of Road Transport and Highways, India Road Transport : Table 1A.10 : Statewise Rural Road Density Per 1000 Population http://mospi.nic.in/Mospi_New/upload/Infra_stat_2010/1.ch_road.pdf

wb:indicator.wb:name: Number of road traffic deaths
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Number of road traffic deaths
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Source: Ministry of Road Transport and Highways (2011)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Urban Road Density (KMs Per 1000 Population)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Urban roads density is measured in KMs of Urban roads in the area (State, District) divided by population in thousands in that area (State, District) Urban roads are roads within a limits of a Municipality, Military Cantonment, Port o a Railway Authority.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Source: Transport and Research Wing, Ministry of Road Transport and Highways, India Road Transport : Table 1A.8 : Statewise Rural Road Density Per 1000 Population http://mospi.nic.in/Mospi_New/upload/Infra_stat_2010/1.ch_road.pdf

wb:indicator.wb:name: Non-energy commodities, 2000=100, current$
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Non-energy index, a Laspeyres Index with fixed weights based on 2002-2004 average developing countries export values, for 34 commodities contain in the agriculture, fertilizer, and metals and minerals indices.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Agr: Food: Other food, 2000=100, current$
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Other food index includes bananas, beef, chicken meat, oranges and sugar.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Agr: Raw:2 Oth raw materials, 2000=100, current$
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Other raw materials index includes cotton, natural rubber and tobacco.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Scientific and technical journal articles
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Scientific and technical journal articles refer to the number of scientific and engineering articles published in the following fields: physics, biology, chemistry, mathematics, clinical medicine, biomedical research, engineering and technology, and earth and space sciences.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: National Science Foundation, Science and Engineering Indicators.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Patent applications, nonresidents
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Patent applications are worldwide patent applications filed through the Patent Cooperation Treaty procedure or with a national patent office for exclusive rights for an invention--a product or process that provides a new way of doing something or offers a new technical solution to a problem. A patent provides protection for the invention to the owner of the patent for a limited period, generally 20 years.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO), World Intellectual Property Indicators and www.wipo.int/econ_stat. The International Bureau of WIPO assumes no responsibility with respect to the transformation of these data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Patent applications, residents
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Patent applications are worldwide patent applications filed through the Patent Cooperation Treaty procedure or with a national patent office for exclusive rights for an invention--a product or process that provides a new way of doing something or offers a new technical solution to a problem. A patent provides protection for the invention to the owner of the patent for a limited period, generally 20 years.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO), World Intellectual Property Indicators and www.wipo.int/econ_stat. The International Bureau of WIPO assumes no responsibility with respect to the transformation of these data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Trademark applications, aggregate direct
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Trademark applications filed are applications to register a trademark with a national or regional Intellectual Property (IP) office. A trademark is a distinctive sign which identifies certain goods or services as those produced or provided by a specific person or enterprise. A trademark provides protection to the owner of the mark by ensuring the exclusive right to use it to identify goods or services, or to authorize another to use it in return for payment. The period of protection varies, but a trademark can be renewed indefinitely beyond the time limit on payment of additional fees. Aggregate direct trademark applications are those filed by applicants without regard to the residency of the applicant. This figure is used when the national office does not provide a breakdown by direct resident and direct nonresident applications.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO), World Intellectual Property Indicators and www.wipo.int/econ_stat. The International Bureau of WIPO assumes no responsibility with respect to the transformation of these data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Trademark applications, Madrid
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Trademark applications filed are applications to register a trademark with a national or regional Intellectual Property (IP) office. A trademark is a distinctive sign which identifies certain goods or services as those produced or provided by a specific person or enterprise. A trademark provides protection to the owner of the mark by ensuring the exclusive right to use it to identify goods or services, or to authorize another to use it in return for payment. The period of protection varies, but a trademark can be renewed indefinitely beyond the time limit on payment of additional fees. Madrid trademark applications are those received by the national or regional IP office as a result of an international application filed via the WIPO-administered Madrid System.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO), World Intellectual Property Indicators and www.wipo.int/econ_stat. The International Bureau of WIPO assumes no responsibility with respect to the transformation of these data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Trademark applications, direct nonresident
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Trademark applications filed are applications to register a trademark with a national or regional Intellectual Property (IP) office. A trademark is a distinctive sign which identifies certain goods or services as those produced or provided by a specific person or enterprise. A trademark provides protection to the owner of the mark by ensuring the exclusive right to use it to identify goods or services, or to authorize another to use it in return for payment. The period of protection varies, but a trademark can be renewed indefinitely beyond the time limit on payment of additional fees. Direct nonresident trademark applications are those filed by applicants from abroad directly at a given national IP office.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO), World Intellectual Property Indicators and www.wipo.int/econ_stat. The International Bureau of WIPO assumes no responsibility with respect to the transformation of these data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Trademark applications, direct resident
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Trademark applications filed are applications to register a trademark with a national or regional Intellectual Property (IP) office. A trademark is a distinctive sign which identifies certain goods or services as those produced or provided by a specific person or enterprise. A trademark provides protection to the owner of the mark by ensuring the exclusive right to use it to identify goods or services, or to authorize another to use it in return for payment. The period of protection varies, but a trademark can be renewed indefinitely beyond the time limit on payment of additional fees. Direct resident trademark applications are those filed by domestic applicants directly at a given national IP office.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO), World Intellectual Property Indicators and www.wipo.int/econ_stat. The International Bureau of WIPO assumes no responsibility with respect to the transformation of these data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Trademark applications, total
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Trademark applications filed are applications to register a trademark with a national or regional Intellectual Property (IP) office. A trademark is a distinctive sign which identifies certain goods or services as those produced or provided by a specific person or enterprise. A trademark provides protection to the owner of the mark by ensuring the exclusive right to use it to identify goods or services, or to authorize another to use it in return for payment. The period of protection varies, but a trademark can be renewed indefinitely beyond the time limit on payment of additional fees.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO), World Intellectual Property Indicators and www.wipo.int/econ_stat. The International Bureau of WIPO assumes no responsibility with respect to the transformation of these data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Industrial Production, constant US$
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: An economic indicator that measures changes in output for the industrial sector of the economy. The industrial sector includes manufacturing, mining, and utilities. Data is in constant US$, and not seasonally adjusted. The base year is 2005.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Industrial Production, constant US$, seas. adj.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: An economic indicator that measures changes in output for the industrial sector of the economy. The industrial sector includes manufacturing, mining, and utilities. Data is in constant US$, seasonally adjusted. The base year is 2005.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: State institutions with adequately established/differentiated power structure index (1=lowest; 10=highest)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: State institutions with adequately established/differentiated power structure index (1=lowest; 10=highest) is a composite indicator (Bertelsmann Transformation Index) that combines stateness and rule of law categories--about 8 indicators are aggregated. Stateness focuses on the existence of adequately established and differentiated power structures in the country, while rule of law focuses on the existence of check and balance mechanisms that can monitor each other and ensure enforcement of civil rights.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates from Bertelsmann Transformation Index.

wb:indicator.wb:name: CPIA business regulatory environment rating (1=low to 6=high)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Business regulatory environment assesses the extent to which the legal, regulatory, and policy environments help or hinder private businesses in investing, creating jobs, and becoming more productive.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank Group, CPIA database (http://www.worldbank.org/ida).

wb:indicator.wb:name: CPIA debt policy rating (1=low to 6=high)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Debt policy assesses whether the debt management strategy is conducive to minimizing budgetary risks and ensuring long-term debt sustainability.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank Group, CPIA database (http://www.worldbank.org/ida).

wb:indicator.wb:name: CPIA economic management cluster average (1=low to 6=high)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The economic management cluster includes macroeconomic management, fiscal policy, and debt policy.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank Group, CPIA database (http://www.worldbank.org/ida).

wb:indicator.wb:name: CPIA policy and institutions for environmental sustainability rating (1=low to 6=high)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Policy and institutions for environmental sustainability assess the extent to which environmental policies foster the protection and sustainable use of natural resources and the management of pollution.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank Group, CPIA database (http://www.worldbank.org/ida).

wb:indicator.wb:name: CPIA quality of budgetary and financial management rating (1=low to 6=high)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Quality of budgetary and financial management assesses the extent to which there is a comprehensive and credible budget linked to policy priorities, effective financial management systems, and timely and accurate accounting and fiscal reporting, including timely and audited public accounts.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank Group, CPIA database (http://www.worldbank.org/ida).

wb:indicator.wb:name: CPIA financial sector rating (1=low to 6=high)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Financial sector assesses the structure of the financial sector and the policies and regulations that affect it.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank Group, CPIA database (http://www.worldbank.org/ida).

wb:indicator.wb:name: CPIA fiscal policy rating (1=low to 6=high)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Fiscal policy assesses the short- and medium-term sustainability of fiscal policy (taking into account monetary and exchange rate policy and the sustainability of the public debt) and its impact on growth.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank Group, CPIA database (http://www.worldbank.org/ida).

wb:indicator.wb:name: CPIA gender equality rating (1=low to 6=high)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gender equality assesses the extent to which the country has installed institutions and programs to enforce laws and policies that promote equal access for men and women in education, health, the economy, and protection under law.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank Group, CPIA database (http://www.worldbank.org/ida).

wb:indicator.wb:name: CPIA building human resources rating (1=low to 6=high)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Building human resources assesses the national policies and public and private sector service delivery that affect the access to and quality of health and education services, including prevention and treatment of HIV/AIDS, tuberculosis, and malaria.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank Group, CPIA database (http://www.worldbank.org/ida).

wb:indicator.wb:name: IDA resource allocation index (1=low to 6=high)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: IDA Resource Allocation Index is obtained by calculating the average score for each cluster and then by averaging those scores. For each of 16 criteria countries are rated on a scale of 1 (low) to 6 (high).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank Group, CPIA database (http://www.worldbank.org/ida).

wb:indicator.wb:name: CPIA macroeconomic management rating (1=low to 6=high)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Macroeconomic management assesses the monetary, exchange rate, and aggregate demand policy framework.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank Group, CPIA database (http://www.worldbank.org/ida).

wb:indicator.wb:name: CPIA quality of public administration rating (1=low to 6=high)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Quality of public administration assesses the extent to which civilian central government staff is structured to design and implement government policy and deliver services effectively.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank Group, CPIA database (http://www.worldbank.org/ida).

wb:indicator.wb:name: CPIA equity of public resource use rating (1=low to 6=high)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Equity of public resource use assesses the extent to which the pattern of public expenditures and revenue collection affects the poor and is consistent with national poverty reduction priorities.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank Group, CPIA database (http://www.worldbank.org/ida).

wb:indicator.wb:name: CPIA property rights and rule-based governance rating (1=low to 6=high)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Property rights and rule-based governance assess the extent to which private economic activity is facilitated by an effective legal system and rule-based governance structure in which property and contract rights are reliably respected and enforced.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank Group, CPIA database (http://www.worldbank.org/ida).

wb:indicator.wb:name: CPIA social protection rating (1=low to 6=high)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Social protection and labor assess government policies in social protection and labor market regulations that reduce the risk of becoming poor, assist those who are poor to better manage further risks, and ensure a minimal level of welfare to all people.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank Group, CPIA database (http://www.worldbank.org/ida).

wb:indicator.wb:name: CPIA public sector management and institutions cluster average (1=low to 6=high)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The public sector management and institutions cluster includes property rights and rule-based governance, quality of budgetary and financial management, efficiency of revenue mobilization, quality of public administration, and transparency, accountability, and corruption in the public sector.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank Group, CPIA database (http://www.worldbank.org/ida).

wb:indicator.wb:name: CPIA efficiency of revenue mobilization rating (1=low to 6=high)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Efficiency of revenue mobilization assesses the overall pattern of revenue mobilization--not only the de facto tax structure, but also revenue from all sources as actually collected.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank Group, CPIA database (http://www.worldbank.org/ida).

wb:indicator.wb:name: CPIA policies for social inclusion/equity cluster average (1=low to 6=high)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The policies for social inclusion and equity cluster includes gender equality, equity of public resource use, building human resources, social protection and labor, and policies and institutions for environmental sustainability.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank Group, CPIA database (http://www.worldbank.org/ida).

wb:indicator.wb:name: CPIA structural policies cluster average (1=low to 6=high)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The structural policies cluster includes trade, financial sector, and business regulatory environment.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank Group, CPIA database (http://www.worldbank.org/ida).

wb:indicator.wb:name: CPIA trade rating (1=low to 6=high)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Trade assesses how the policy framework fosters trade in goods.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank Group, CPIA database (http://www.worldbank.org/ida).

wb:indicator.wb:name: CPIA transparency, accountability, and corruption in the public sector rating (1=low to 6=high)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Transparency, accountability, and corruption in the public sector assess the extent to which the executive can be held accountable for its use of funds and for the results of its actions by the electorate and by the legislature and judiciary, and the extent to which public employees within the executive are required to account for administrative decisions, use of resources, and results obtained. The three main dimensions assessed here are the accountability of the executive to oversight institutions and of public employees for their performance, access of civil society to information on public affairs, and state capture by narrow vested interests.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank Group, CPIA database (http://www.worldbank.org/ida).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Effective and accountable government index (0=lowest; 7=highest)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Effective and accountable government index (0=lowest; 7=highest) is a Freedom House indicator that attempts to capture how resources are managed using the following questions: (1) Are the executive, legislative, and judicial branches of government able to oversee the actions of one another and hold each other accountable for any excessive exercise of power? (2) Does the state system ensure that people's political choices are free from domination by the specific interests of power groups (e.g., the military, foreign powers, totalitarian parties, regional hierarchies, and/or economic oligarchies)? (3) Is the civil service selected, promoted, and dismissed on the basis of open competition and by merit? (4) Is the state engaged in issues reflecting the interests of women; ethnic, religious, and other distinct groups; and disabled people?
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates from Freedom House data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Public access to information index (0=lowest; 100=highest)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Public access to information index (0=lowest; 100=highest) is a Global Integrity indicator that captures the in law and in practice status of access to information in a country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates from Global Integrity Index.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Overall level of statistical capacity (scale 0 - 100)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The Statistical Capacity Indicator (SCI) provides an overview of the statistical capacity of over 140 developing countries. It is based on a diagnostic framework developed with a view to assessing the capacity of national statistical systems and monitoring progress in statistical development over time. The framework has three dimensions: statistical methodology; source data; and periodicity and timeliness. For each dimension, a country is scored against specific criteria, using information available from the World Bank, IMF, UN, UNESCO, and WHO. A composite score for each dimension and an overall score combining all three dimensions are derived for each country on a scale of 0-100. A score of 100 indicates that the country meets all the criteria.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, Bulletin Board on Statistical Capacity (http://bbsc.worldbank.org).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Burden of customs procedure, WEF (1=extremely inefficient to 7=extremely efficient)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Burden of Customs Procedure measures business executives' perceptions of their country's efficiency of customs procedures. The rating ranges from 1 to 7, with a higher score indicating greater efficiency. Data are from the World Economic Forum's Executive Opinion Survey, conducted for 30 years in collaboration with 150 partner institutes. The 2009 round included more than 13,000 respondents from 133 countries. Sampling follows a dual stratification based on company size and the sector of activity. Data are collected online or through in-person interviews. Responses are aggregated using sector-weighted averaging. The data for the latest year are combined with the data for the previous year to create a two-year moving average. Respondents evaluated the efficiency of customs procedures in their country. The lowest score (1) rates the customs procedure as extremely inefficient, and the highest score (7) as extremely efficient.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Economic Forum, Global Competiveness Report and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Quality of port infrastructure, WEF (1=extremely underdeveloped to 7=well developed and efficient by international standards)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The Quality of Port Infrastructure measures business executives' perception of their country's port facilities. Data are from the World Economic Forum's Executive Opinion Survey, conducted for 30 years in collaboration with 150 partner institutes. The 2009 round included more than 13,000 respondents from 133 countries. Sampling follows a dual stratification based on company size and the sector of activity. Data are collected online or through in-person interviews. Responses are aggregated using sector-weighted averaging. The data for the latest year are combined with the data for the previous year to create a two-year moving average. Scores range from 1 (port infrastructure considered extremely underdeveloped) to 7 (port infrastructure considered efficient by international standards). Respondents in landlocked countries were asked how accessible are port facilities (1 = extremely inaccessible; 7 = extremely accessible).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Economic Forum, Global Competiveness Report.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Interest Rates (10YR)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: A country's bond yield with a 10 year maturity
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Agr: Raw materials, 2000=100, current$
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Agricultural raw materials index includes timber and other raw materials.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Iron ore, cents/dmtu, current$
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Iron ore (Brazil), VALE (formerly CVRD) Carajas sinter feed, contract price, f.o.b. Ponta da Madeira. Unit dry metric ton unit (dmtu) stands for mt 1% Fe-unit. Prior to year 2010 annual contract prices.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Vale; CVRD; UNCTAD; World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Sovereign Bond Interest Rate Spreads, basis points over US Treasuries
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Air transport, registered carrier departures worldwide
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Registered carrier departures worldwide are domestic takeoffs and takeoffs abroad of air carriers registered in the country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Civil Aviation Organization, Civil Aviation Statistics of the World and ICAO staff estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Air transport, freight (million ton-km)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Air freight is the volume of freight, express, and diplomatic bags carried on each flight stage (operation of an aircraft from takeoff to its next landing), measured in metric tons times kilometers traveled.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Civil Aviation Organization, Civil Aviation Statistics of the World and ICAO staff estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Air transport, passengers carried
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Air passengers carried include both domestic and international aircraft passengers of air carriers registered in the country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Civil Aviation Organization, Civil Aviation Statistics of the World and ICAO staff estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Access to an all-season road (% of rural population)
wb:indicator.wb:source: International Development Association - Results Measurement System
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Access to an all-season road is measured as the proportion of rural people who live within 2 kilometers (typically equivalent to a 20-minute walk) of an all-season road. An all-season road is a road that is motorable all year by the prevailing means of rural transport (often a pick-up or a truck which does not have four-wheel-drive). Predictable interruptions of short duration during inclement weather (e.g. heavy rainfall) are acceptable, particularly on low volume roads. The preferred approach to measuring this indicator is by analysis of household surveys that include appropriate questions about access to transport.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Compiled by World Bank staff from household surveys, specifically Living Standard Measurement Surveys (LSMS), Income/Expenditure Household Surveys (IES), Poverty Surveys (PS) and Core Welfare Indicators Questionnaires (CWIQ) carried out between 1994 to 2003.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Road sector diesel fuel consumption (kt of oil equivalent)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Diesel is heavy oils used as a fuel for internal combustion in diesel engines.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Road Federation, World Road Statistics and electronic files, except where noted, and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Road sector diesel fuel consumption per capita (kg of oil equivalent)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Diesel is heavy oils used as a fuel for internal combustion in diesel engines.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Road Federation, World Road Statistics and electronic files, except where noted, and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Road density (km of road per 100 sq. km of land area)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Road density is the ratio of the length of the country's total road network to the country's land area. The road network includes all roads in the country: motorways, highways, main or national roads, secondary or regional roads, and other urban and rural roads.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Road Federation, World Road Statistics and electronic files, except where noted.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Road sector energy consumption (kt of oil equivalent)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Road sector energy consumption is the total energy used in the road sector including petroleum products, natural gas, electricity, and combustible renewable and waste.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Road Federation, World Road Statistics and electronic files, except where noted, and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Road sector energy consumption per capita (kg of oil equivalent)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Road sector energy consumption is the total energy used in the road sector including petroleum products, natural gas, electricity, and combustible renewable and waste.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Road Federation, World Road Statistics and electronic files, except where noted, and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Road sector energy consumption (% of total energy consumption)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Road sector energy consumption is the total energy used in the road sector including petroleum products, natural gas, electricity, and combustible renewable and waste. Total energy consumption is the total country energy consumption.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Road Federation, World Road Statistics and electronic files, except where noted, and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Roads, goods transported (million ton-km)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Goods transported by road are the volume of goods transported by road vehicles, measured in millions of metric tons times kilometers traveled.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Road Federation, World Road Statistics and electronic files, except where noted.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Roads, paved (% of total roads)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Paved roads are those surfaced with crushed stone (macadam) and hydrocarbon binder or bituminized agents, with concrete, or with cobblestones, as a percentage of all the country's roads, measured in length.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Road Federation, World Road Statistics and electronic files, except where noted.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Roads, passengers carried (million passenger-km)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Passengers carried by road are the number of passengers transported by road times kilometers traveled.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Road Federation, World Road Statistics and electronic files, except where noted.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Road sector gasoline fuel consumption (kt of oil equivalent)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gasoline is light hydrocarbon oil use in internal combustion engine such as motor vehicles, excluding aircraft.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Road Federation, World Road Statistics and electronic files, except where noted, and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Road sector gasoline fuel consumption per capita (kg of oil equivalent)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gasoline is light hydrocarbon oil use in internal combustion engine such as motor vehicles, excluding aircraft.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Road Federation, World Road Statistics and electronic files, except where noted, and International Energy Agency (IEA Statistics © OECD/IEA, http://www.iea.org/stats/index.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Roads, total network (km)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total road network includes motorways, highways, and main or national roads, secondary or regional roads, and all other roads in a country. A motorway is a road designed and built for motor traffic that separates the traffic flowing in opposite directions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Road Federation, World Road Statistics and electronic files, except where noted.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Railways, goods transported (million ton-km)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Goods transported by railway are the volume of goods transported by railway, measured in metric tons times kilometers traveled.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, Transportation, Water, and Information and Communications Technologies Department, Transport Division.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Railways, passengers carried (million passenger-km)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Passengers carried by railway are the number of passengers transported by rail times kilometers traveled.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, Transportation, Water, and Information and Communications Technologies Department, Transport Division.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Rail lines (total route-km)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Rail lines are the length of railway route available for train service, irrespective of the number of parallel tracks.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, Transportation, Water, and Information and Communications Technologies Department, Transport Division.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Liner shipping connectivity index (maximum value in 2004 = 100)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The Liner Shipping Connectivity Index captures how well countries are connected to global shipping networks. It is computed by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) based on five components of the maritime transport sector: number of ships, their container-carrying capacity, maximum vessel size, number of services, and number of companies that deploy container ships in a country's ports. For each component a country's value is divided by the maximum value of each component in 2004, the five components are averaged for each country, and the average is divided by the maximum average for 2004 and multiplied by 100. The index generates a value of 100 for the country with the highest average index in 2004. . The underlying data come from Containerisation International Online.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, Review of Maritime Transport 2010.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Container port traffic (TEU: 20 foot equivalent units)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Port container traffic measures the flow of containers from land to sea transport modes., and vice versa, in twenty-foot equivalent units (TEUs), a standard-size container. Data refer to coastal shipping as well as international journeys. Transshipment traffic is counted as two lifts at the intermediate port (once to off-load and again as an outbound lift) and includes empty units.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Containerisation International, Containerisation International Yearbook.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Motor vehicles (per 1,000 people)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Motor vehicles include cars, buses, and freight vehicles but do not include two-wheelers. Population refers to midyear population in the year for which data are available.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Road Federation, World Road Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Passenger cars (per 1,000 people)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Passenger cars refer to road motor vehicles, other than two-wheelers, intended for the carriage of passengers and designed to seat no more than nine people (including the driver).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Road Federation, World Road Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Vehicles (per km of road)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Vehicles per kilometer of road include cars, buses, and freight vehicles but do not include two-wheelers. Roads refer to motorways, highways, main or national roads, secondary or regional roads, and other roads. A motorway is a road specially designed and built for motor traffic that separates the traffic flowing in opposite directions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Road Federation, World Road Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Mobile cellular subscriptions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Mobile cellular telephone subscriptions are subscriptions to a public mobile telephone service using cellular technology, which provide access to the public switched telephone network. Post-paid and prepaid subscriptions are included.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication/ICT Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Mobile cellular telephone users, female (% of population)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Mobile cellular telephone subscriptions are subscriptions to a public mobile telephone service using cellular technology, which provide access to the public switched telephone network. Post-paid and prepaid subscriptions are included.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication/ICT Development Report and database

wb:indicator.wb:name: Mobile cellular telephone users, male (% of population)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Mobile cellular telephone subscriptions are subscriptions to a public mobile telephone service using cellular technology, which provide access to the public switched telephone network. Post-paid and prepaid subscriptions are included.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication/ICT Development Report and database

wb:indicator.wb:name: Mobile cellular subscriptions (per 100 people)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Mobile cellular telephone subscriptions are subscriptions to a public mobile telephone service using cellular technology, which provide access to the public switched telephone network. Post-paid and prepaid subscriptions are included.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication/ICT Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Mobile phone subscribers (per 1,000 people)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Please cite the International Telecommunication Union for third-party use of these data. Mobile telephone subscribers are subscribers to a public mobile telephone service using cellular technology.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Mobile cellular - price of 3-minute local call (off-peak rate - current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Please cite the International Telecommunication Union for third-party use of these data. The price of a three minute off-peak rate call from a mobile cellular telephone to a mobile cellular subscriber of the same network. A note indicates whether taxes are included (preferred) or not, or if the price refers to a pre-paid or post-paid subscription. This indicator is expressed in US dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Mobile cellular - price of 3-minute local call (peak rate - current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Please cite the International Telecommunication Union for third-party use of these data. The price of a three minute peak rate call from a mobile cellular telephone to a mobile cellular subscriber of the same network. A note indicates whether taxes are included (preferred) or not, or if the price refers to a pre-paid or post-paid subscription. This indicator is expressed in US dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Mobile cellular - price of 3-minute local call (off-peak rate - current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Please cite the International Telecommunication Union for third-party use of these data. The price of a three minute off-peak rate call from a mobile cellular telephone to a mobile cellular subscriber of the same network. A note indicates whether taxes are included (preferred) or not, or if the price refers to a pre-paid or post-paid subscription. This indicator is expressed in national currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Mobile cellular - price of 3-minute local call (peak rate - current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Please cite the International Telecommunication Union for third-party use of these data. The price of a three minute peak rate call from a mobile cellular telephone to a mobile cellular subscriber of the same network. A note indicates whether taxes are included (preferred) or not, or if the price refers to a pre-paid or post-paid subscription. This indicator is expressed in national currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Mobile cellular monthly subscription (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Please cite the International Telecommunication Union for third-party use of these data. The monthly subscription charge for mobile cellular service. Due to the variety of plans available in many countries, it is preferable to use the tariff with the cheapest initiation/connection charge. If prepaid services are used (for those countries that have more prepaid than post-paid subscribers), the monthly subscription charge would be zero. If the plan includes free minutes, this should be put in a note. A note should indicate whether taxes are included (preferred) or not and what the rate is. This indicator is expressed in US dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Mobile cellular monthly subscription (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Please cite the International Telecommunication Union for third-party use of these data. The monthly subscription charge for mobile cellular service. Due to the variety of plans available in many countries, it is preferable to use the tariff with the cheapest initiation/connection charge. If prepaid services are used (for those countries that have more prepaid than post-paid subscribers), the monthly subscription charge would be zero. If the plan includes free minutes, this should be put in a note. A note should indicate whether taxes are included (preferred) or not and what the rate is. This indicator is expressed in local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Mobile cellular postpaid connection charge (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Please cite the International Telecommunication Union for third-party use of these data. The initial, one-time charge for a new postpaid subscription. Refundable deposits should not be counted. Although some operators waive the connection charge, this does not include the cost of the Subscriber Identity Module (SIM) card. The price of the SIM card should be included in the connection charge. It should also be noted if free minutes or free SMS are included in the connection charge. Taxes should be included. If not included, it should be specified in a note including the tax rate applicable. This indicator is expressed in local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Mobile cellular postpaid connection charge (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Please cite the International Telecommunication Union for third-party use of these data. The initial, one-time charge for a new postpaid subscription. Refundable deposits should not be counted. Although some operators waive the connection charge, this does not include the cost of the Subscriber Identity Module (SIM) card. The price of the SIM card should be included in the connection charge. It should also be noted if free minutes or free SMS are included in the connection charge. Taxes should be included. If not included, it should be specified in a note including the tax rate applicable. This indicator is expressed in local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Mobile cellular prepaid connection charge (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Please cite the International Telecommunication Union for third-party use of these data. The initial, one-time charge for a new postpaid subscription. Refundable deposits should not be counted. Although some operators waive the connection charge, this does not include the cost of the Subscriber Identity Module (SIM) card. The price of the SIM card should be included in the connection charge. It should also be noted if free minutes or free SMS are included in the connection charge. Taxes should be included. If not included, it should be specified in a note including the tax rate applicable. This indicator is expressed in local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Mobile cellular prepaid connection charge (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Please cite the International Telecommunication Union for third-party use of these data. The initial, one-time charge for a new postpaid subscription. Refundable deposits should not be counted. Although some operators waive the connection charge, this does not include the cost of the Subscriber Identity Module (SIM) card. The price of the SIM card should be included in the connection charge. It should also be noted if free minutes or free SMS are included in the connection charge. Taxes should be included. If not included, it should be specified in a note including the tax rate applicable. This indicator is expressed in local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Personal computers (per 100 people)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Personal computers are self-contained computers designed to be used by a single individual.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication/ICT Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Price of a 3-minute fixed telephone local call (off-peak rate - current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Please cite the International Telecommunication Union for third-party use of these data. Local call refers to the cost of an off-peak rate 3-minute call within the same exchange area using the subscriber's own terminal (i.e., not from a public telephone). This indicator is expressed in US dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Price of a 3-minute fixed telephone local call (peak rate - current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Please cite the International Telecommunication Union for third-party use of these data. Local call refers to the cost of peak rate 3-minute call within the same exchange area using the subscriber's own terminal (i.e., not from a public telephone). This indicator is expressed in US dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Telephone average cost of call to US (US$ per three minutes)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Cost of international call to U.S. is the cost of a three-minute, peak rate, fixed line call from the country to the United States.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication/ICT Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Price of a 3-minute fixed telephone local call (off-peak rate - current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Please cite the International Telecommunication Union for third-party use of these data. Local call refers to the cost of an off-peak rate 3-minute call within the same exchange area using the subscriber's own terminal (i.e., not from a public telephone). This indicator is expressed in national currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Price of a 3-minute fixed telephone local call (peak rate - current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Please cite the International Telecommunication Union for third-party use of these data. Local call refers to the cost of peak rate 3-minute call within the same exchange area using the subscriber's own terminal (i.e., not from a public telephone). This indicator is expressed in local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Business telephone connection charge (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Please cite the International Telecommunication Union for third-party use of these data. Installation (or connection) refers to the one-off charge involved in applying for business basic telephone service. Where there are different charges for different exchange areas, the charge for the largest urban area should be used and specified in a note. This indicator is expressed in US dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Business telephone connection charge (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Please cite the International Telecommunication Union for third-party use of these data. Installation (or connection) refers to the one-off charge involved in applying for business basic telephone service. Where there are different charges for different exchange areas, the charge for the largest urban area should be used and specified in a note. This indicator is expressed in local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Business telephone monthly subscription (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Please cite the International Telecommunication Union for third-party use of these data. Monthly subscription refers to the recurring fixed charge for subscribing to the PSTN in US$. The charge should cover the rental of the line but not the rental of the terminal (e.g., telephone set) where the terminal equipment market is liberalized. Separate charges should be stated where appropriate, for first and subsequent lines. If the rental charge includes any allowance for free or reduced rate call units, this should be indicated. If there are different charges for different exchange areas, the largest urban area should be used and specified in a note. This indicator is expressed in US dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Business telephone monthly subscription (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Please cite the International Telecommunication Union for third-party use of these data. Monthly subscription refers to the recurring fixed charge for subscribing to the PSTN. The charge should cover the rental of the line but not the rental of the terminal (e.g., telephone set) where the terminal equipment market is liberalized. Separate charges should be stated where appropriate, for first and subsequent lines. If the rental charge includes any allowance for free or reduced rate call units, this should be indicated. If there are different charges for different exchange areas, the largest urban area should be used and specified in a note. This indicator is expressed in local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Residential telephone connection charge (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Please cite the International Telecommunication Union for third-party use of these data. Installation refers to the one time charge involved in applying for basic telephone service for business purposes. Where there are different charges for different exchange areas, the charge is generally for the largest urban area unless otherwise noted. This indicator is expressed in US dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Residential telephone connection charge (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Please cite the International Telecommunication Union for third-party use of these data. Installation refers to the one time charge involved in applying for basic telephone service for business purposes. Where there are different charges for different exchange areas, the charge is generally for the largest urban area unless otherwise noted. This indicator is expressed in national currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Telephone faults cleared by next working day (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Telephone faults cleared by next working day are the percentage of faults in the public switched telephone network that have been corrected by the end of the next working day.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Telephone faults (per 100 mainlines)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Telephone mainline faults is the number of reported telephone faults for the year per 100 telephone mainlines.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication/ICT Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Fixed telephone service investment (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Please cite the International Telecommunication Union for third-party use of these data. Annual investment on equipment for fixed telephone service. This indicator is expressed in US dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Fixed telephone service investment (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Please cite the International Telecommunication Union for third-party use of these data. Annual investment on equipment for fixed telephone service. This indicator is expressed in local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Telephone lines
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Telephone lines are fixed telephone lines that connect a subscriber's terminal equipment to the public switched telephone network and that have a port on a telephone exchange. Integrated services digital network channels ands fixed wireless subscribers are included.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication/ICT Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Telephone lines (per 100 people)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Telephone lines are fixed telephone lines that connect a subscriber's terminal equipment to the public switched telephone network and that have a port on a telephone exchange. Integrated services digital network channels ands fixed wireless subscribers are included.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication/ICT Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Telephone mainlines (per 1,000 people)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Please cite the International Telecommunication Union for third-party use of these data. Telephone mainlines are fixed telephone lines connecting a subscriber to the telephone exchange equipment.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Revenue from fixed telephone service (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Please cite the International Telecommunication Union for third-party use of these data. Revenue received from fixed telephone connection, subscription and calls. This indicator is expressed in US dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: "International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates. "

wb:indicator.wb:name: Revenue from fixed telephone service (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Please cite the International Telecommunication Union for third-party use of these data. Revenue received from fixed telephone connection, subscription and calls. This indicator is expressed in local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: "International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates. "

wb:indicator.wb:name: Residential monthly telephone subscription (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Please cite the International Telecommunication Union for third-party use of these data. Monthly subscription refers to the recurring fixed charge for subscribing to the PSTN. The charge should cover the rental of the line, but not the rental of the terminal (e.g., telephone set) where the terminal equipment market is liberalized. Separate charges should be stated where appropriate, for first and subsequent lines. If the rental charge includes any allowance for free or reduced rate call units, this should be indicated. If there are different charges for different exchange areas, the largest urban area should be used and specified in a note. This indicator is expressed in US dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Residential monthly telephone subscription (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Please cite the International Telecommunication Union for third-party use of these data. Monthly subscription refers to the recurring fixed charge for subscribing to the PSTN. The charge should cover the rental of the line, but not the rental of the terminal (e.g., telephone set) where the terminal equipment market is liberalized. Separate charges should be stated where appropriate, for first and subsequent lines. If the rental charge includes any allowance for free or reduced rate call units, this should be indicated. If there are different charges for different exchange areas, the largest urban area should be used and specified in a note. This indicator is expressed in local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Population coverage of mobile cellular telephony (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Please cite the International Telecommunication Union for third-party use of these data. Percentage of population covered by mobile cellular telephony refers to the percentage of a country’s inhabitants that live within areas served by a mobile cellular signal, irrespective of whether or not they choose to use it. This should not be confused with the percentage of the land area covered by a mobile cellular signal or the percentage of the population that subscribe to mobile cellular service. Note that this measures the theoretical ability to use mobile cellular services if one has a cellular telephone and a subscription.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Mobile communication investment (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Please cite the International Telecommunication Union for third-party use of these data. Annual investment on equipment for mobile communication networks. Data is in US dollar.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Mobile communication investment (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Please cite the International Telecommunication Union for third-party use of these data. Annual investment on equipment for mobile communication networks. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Revenue from mobile communication (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Please cite the International Telecommunication Union for third-party use of these data. Revenues from the provision of all types of mobile communications services such cellular, private trunked radio and radio paging. This indicator is expressed in US
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: "International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates. "

wb:indicator.wb:name: Revenue from mobile communication (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Please cite the International Telecommunication Union for third-party use of these data. Revenues from the provision of all types of mobile communications services such cellular, private trunked radio and radio paging. This indicator is expressed in loc
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: "International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates. "

wb:indicator.wb:name: Fixed broadband Internet subscribers
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Fixed broadband Internet subscribers are the number of broadband subscribers with a digital subscriber line, cable modem, or other high-speed technology.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication/ICT Development Report and database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Fixed broadband Internet subscribers (per 100 people)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Fixed broadband Internet subscribers are the number of broadband subscribers with a digital subscriber line, cable modem, or other high-speed technology.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication/ICT Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Broadband subscribers (per 1,000 people)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Please cite the International Telecommunication Union for third-party use of these data. Broadband subscribers are the total number of broadband subscribers with a digital subscriber line, cable modem, or other high-speed technologies. Reporting countries may have different definitions of broadband, so data are not strictly comparable across countries.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: International Internet bandwidth (Mbps)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: International Internet bandwidth is the contracted capacity of international connections between countries for transmitting Internet traffic.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication/ICT Development Report and database, and TeleGeography.

wb:indicator.wb:name: International Internet bandwidth (bits per person)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: International Internet bandwidth is the contracted capacity of international connections between countries for transmitting Internet traffic.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication/ICT Development Report and database, TeleGeography, and World Bank population estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Fixed broadband Internet connection charge (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Fixed (Wired) broadband Internet connection charge is the initial, one-time charge for a new fixed (wired) broadband Internet connection. The tariffs should represent the cheapest fixed (wired) broadband entry plan. Refundable deposits should not be counted. Taxes should be included. If not included, it should be specified in a note including the applicable tax rate. This indicator is expressed in US dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Fixed broadband Internet connection charge (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Fixed (Wired) broadband Internet connection charge is the initial, one-time charge for a new fixed (wired) broadband Internet connection. The tariffs should represent the cheapest fixed (wired) broadband entry plan. Refundable deposits should not be counted. Taxes should be included. If not included, it should be specified in a note including the applicable tax rate. This indicator is expressed in local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Secure Internet servers
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Secure servers are servers using encryption technology in Internet transactions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Netcraft (http://www.netcraft.com/).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Secure Internet servers (per 1 million people)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Secure servers are servers using encryption technology in Internet transactions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Netcraft (http://www.netcraft.com/) and World Bank population estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Fixed broadband Internet monthly subscription (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Fixed (Wired) broadband Internet monthly subscription is the monthly subscription charge for fixed (wired) broadband Internet service. Fixed (wired) broadband is considered any dedicated connection to the Internet at downstream speeds equal to, or greater than, 256 kbit/s, using DSL. Where several offers are available, preference should be given to the 256 kbit/s connection. Taxes should be included. If not included, it should be specified in a note including the applicable tax rate. This indicator is expressed in local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Fixed broadband Internet monthly subscription (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Fixed (Wired) broadband Internet monthly subscription is the monthly subscription charge for fixed (wired) broadband Internet service. Fixed (wired) broadband is considered any dedicated connection to the Internet at downstream speeds equal to, or greater than, 256 kbit/s, using DSL. Where several offers are available, preference should be given to the 256 kbit/s connection. Taxes should be included. If not included, it should be specified in a note including the applicable tax rate. This indicator is expressed in US dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Internet users
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Internet users are people with access to the worldwide network.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication/ICT Development Report and database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Internet users, female (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Internet users, female (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication/ICT Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Internet users, male (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Internet users, male (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication/ICT Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Internet users (per 100 people)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Internet users are people with access to the worldwide network.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication/ICT Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Internet users (per 1,000 people)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Please cite the International Telecommunication Union for third-party use of these data. Internet users are people with access to the worldwide network.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Public payphones
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Please cite the International Telecommunication Union for third-party use of these data. Total number of all types of public telephones, including coin- and card-operated and public telephones in call offices. Publicly available phones installed in private places should also be included, as should mobile public telephones. All public telephones regardless of capability (e.g., local calls or national only) should be counted. If the national definition of "payphone" differs from that above (e.g., by excluding pay phones in private places), then respondents should indicate their own definition.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Public payphones (per 1,000 people)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Please cite the International Telecommunication Union for third-party use of these data. Total number of all types of public telephones, including coin- and card-operated and public telephones in call offices. Publicly available phones installed in private places should also be included, as should mobile public telephones. All public telephones regardless of capability (e.g., local calls or national only) should be counted. If the national definition of "payphone" differs from that above (e.g., by excluding pay phones in private places), then respondents should indicate their own definition.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Homes with a personal computer (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Please cite the International Telecommunication Union for third-party use of these data. The proportion of households with a computer is calculated by dividing the number of in-scope households with a computer by the total number of inscope households.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Telecommunication Union, World Telecommunication Development Report and database, and World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Daily newspapers (per 1,000 people)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Daily newspapers refer to those published at least four times a week and calculated as average circulation (or copies printed) per 1,000 people.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) Institute for Statistics.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Households with a radio (%)
