wb:indicator.wb:name: Exports of goods and non-financial services, growth (%, constant LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: "The annual rate of growth of exports of goods and non-financial services, as calculated from the constant local currency series. Exports of goods and services represent the value of all goods and other market services provided to or received from the rest of the world. Included is the value of merchandise, freight, insurance, transport, travel, royalties, license fees, and other services. Data are in constant local currency. "
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Export price index (goods and services, 2000=100)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The exports price index is derived by dividing the national accounts exports of goods and services in current U.S. dollars by exports of goods and services in constant 2000 U.S. dollars, with 2000 equaling 100.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Exports of goods and services (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Exports of goods and services represent the value of all goods and other market services provided to the rest of the world. They include the value of merchandise, freight, insurance, transport, travel, royalties, license fees, and other services, such as communication, construction, financial, information, business, personal, and government services. They exclude compensation of employees and investment income (formerly called factor services) and transfer payments.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GDFI - central government (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Central government’s gross domestic fixed investment (gross fixed capital formation) comprises all additions to the stocks of fixed assets (purchases and own-account capital formation), less any sales of second-hand and scrapped fixed assets, by central government. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Changes in inventories (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Inventories are stocks of goods held by firms to meet temporary or unexpected fluctuations in production or sales, and "work in progress." Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Changes in inventories (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Inventories are stocks of goods held by firms to meet temporary or unexpected fluctuations in production or sales, and "work in progress." Data are in current local currency.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Changes in inventories (constant LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Inventories are stocks of goods held by firms to meet temporary or unexpected fluctuations in production or sales, and "work in progress." Data are in constant local currency.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Change in stocks public sector (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Changes in stocks/inventories of public sector comprises the value of the physical changes in (i) stocks of raw materials, work-in-progress (excluding work put in place on structures, roads and other construction projects), and finished goods held by industries, and (ii) stocks of strategic materials or other commodities of importance to the nation held by producers of government services. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Change in stocks public sector (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Changes in stocks/inventories of public sector comprises the value of the physical changes in (i) stocks of raw materials, work-in-progress (excluding work put in place on structures, roads and other construction projects), and finished goods held by industries, and (ii) stocks of strategic materials or other commodities of importance to the nation held by producers of government services. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Change in stocks, public sector (constant LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Changes in stocks/inventories of public sector comprises the value of the physical changes in (i) stocks of raw materials, work-in-progress (excluding work put in place on structures, roads and other construction projects), and finished goods held by industries, and (ii) stocks of strategic materials or other commodities of importance to the nation held by producers of government services. wb:indicator.wb:name: Change in stocks, private sector (constant LCU)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross capital formation (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross capital formation (formerly gross domestic investment) consists of outlays on additions to the fixed assets of the economy plus net changes in the level of inventories. Fixed assets include land improvements (fences, ditches, drains, and so on); plant, machinery, and equipment purchases; and the construction of roads, railways, and the like, including schools, offices, hospitals, private residential dwellings, and commercial and industrial buildings. Inventories are stocks of goods held by firms to meet temporary or unexpected fluctuations in production or sales, and "work in progress." According to the 1993 SNA, net acquisitions of valuables are also considered capital formation. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross capital formation (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross capital formation (formerly gross domestic investment) consists of outlays on additions to the fixed assets of the economy plus net changes in the level of inventories. wb:indicator.wb:name: Imports of goods and services (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Imports of goods and services represent the value of all goods and other market services received from the rest of the world. They exclude compensation of employees and investment income (formerly called factor services) and transfer payments. Data are in current U.S. dollars.

Imports of goods and services represent the value of all goods and other market services received from the rest of the world. wb:indicator.wb:name: Imports of goods and services (constant LCU)

They include the value of merchandise, freight, insurance, transport, travel, royalties, license fees, and other services, such as communication, construction, financial, information, business, personal, and government services. wb:indicator.wb:name: Import price index (goods and services 2000=100)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The imports price index is derived by dividing the national accounts exports of goods and services in current U.S. dollars by imports of goods and services in constant 2000 U.S. dollars, with 2000 equaling 100.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Imports of goods and services (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Imports of goods and services represent the value of all goods and other market services received from the rest of the world. They include the value of merchandise, freight, insurance, transport, travel, royalties, license fees, and other services, such as communication, construction, financial, information, business, personal, and government services. They exclude compensation of employees and investment income (formerly called factor services) and transfer payments.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Merchandise trade to GDP ratio (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Merchandise trade as a share of GDP is the sum of merchandise exports and imports divided by the value of GDP, all in current US dollars and from the national accounts.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: External balance on goods and services (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: External balance on goods and services (formerly resource balance) equals exports of goods and services minus imports of goods and services (previously nonfactor services). Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: External balance on goods and services (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: External balance on goods and services (formerly resource balance) equals exports of goods and services minus imports of goods and services (previously nonfactor services). Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: External balance on goods and services (constant LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: External balance on goods and services (formerly resource balance) equals exports of goods and services minus imports of goods and services (previously nonfactor services). Data are in constant local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: External balance on goods and services (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: External balance on goods and services (formerly resource balance) equals exports of goods and services minus imports of goods and services (previously nonfactor services).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Trade of goods and services (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Trade is the sum of exports and imports of goods and services measured as a share of gross domestic product.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Trade (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Trade is the sum of exports and imports of goods and services measured as a share of gross domestic product.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Terms of trade index (2000=100)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: This is based upon goods and non-financial services from the National Accounts, that is, the terms of trade index shows the national accounts exports price index divided by the imports price index, with 2000 equaling 100.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Terms of trade (goods and services, 2000 = 100)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The terms of trade index shows the national accounts exports price index divided by the imports price index, with 2000 equaling 100.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Government Consumption, current US$, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Government consumption (formerly general government consumption) includes all government current expenditures for purchases of goods and services (including compensation of employees). It also includes most expenditures on national defense and security, but excludes government military expenditures that are part of government capital formation. Data are in current US$, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Government Consumption, current LCU, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Government consumption (formerly general government consumption) includes all government current expenditures for purchases of goods and services (including compensation of employees). It also includes most expenditures on national defense and security, but excludes government military expenditures that are part of government capital formation. Data are in current LCU, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Government Consumption, constant US$, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Government consumption (formerly general government consumption) includes all government current expenditures for purchases of goods and services (including compensation of employees). It also includes most expenditures on national defense and security, but excludes government military expenditures that are part of government capital formation. Data are in constant US$, millions. The base year is 2005.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Government Consumption, constant LCU, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Government consumption (formerly general government consumption) includes all government current expenditures for purchases of goods and services (including compensation of employees). It also includes most expenditures on national defense and security, but excludes government military expenditures that are part of government capital formation. Data are in constant LCU, millions. The base year varies by country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Government Consumption (implicit price deflator constant 2005 USD)
Government Consumption deflator, LCU
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The Government Consumption implicit deflator is the ratio of Government Consumption in current local currency to Government Consumption in constant local currency. The base year varies by country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Private Consumption, current US$, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Private Consumption is the market value of all goods and services, including durable products (such as cars, washing machines, and home computers), purchased by households. It excludes purchases of dwellings but includes imputed rent for owner-occupied dwellings. It also includes payments and fees to governments to obtain permits and licenses. Here, household consumption expenditure includes the expenditures of nonprofit institutions serving households, even when reported separately by the country. Data are in current US$, millions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Private Consumption, current LCU, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Private Consumption is the market value of all goods and services, including durable products (such as cars, washing machines, and home computers), purchased by households. It excludes purchases of dwellings but includes imputed rent for owner-occupied dwellings. It also includes payments and fees to governments to obtain permits and licenses. Here, household consumption expenditure includes the expenditures of nonprofit institutions serving households, even when reported separately by the country. Data are in current LCU, millions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Private Consumption, constant US$, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Private Consumption is the market value of all goods and services, including durable products (such as cars, washing machines, and home computers), purchased by households. It excludes purchases of dwellings but includes imputed rent for owner-occupied dwellings. It also includes payments and fees to governments to obtain permits and licenses. Here, household consumption expenditure includes the expenditures of nonprofit institutions serving households, even when reported separately by the country. Data are in constant US$, millions. The base year is 2005.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Private Consumption, constant LCU, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Private Consumption is the market value of all goods and services, including durable products (such as cars, washing machines, and home computers), purchased by households. It excludes purchases of dwellings but includes imputed rent for owner-occupied dwellings. It also includes payments and fees to governments to obtain permits and licenses. Here, household consumption expenditure includes the expenditures of nonprofit institutions serving households, even when reported separately by the country. Data are in constant LCU, millions. The base year varies by country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Private Consumption (implicit price deflator contant 2005 USD)
Private Consumption deflator, LCU
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The Private Consumption implicit deflator is the ratio of Private Consumption in current local currency to Private Consumption in constant local currency. The base year varies by country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Nominal Effecive Exchange Rate
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: A measure of the value of a currency against a weighted average of several foreign currencies
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream and IMF International Finance Statistics data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Exports GNFS, current US$, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Exports of goods and services represent the value of all goods and other market services provided to the rest of the world. They include the value of merchandise, freight, insurance, transport, travel, royalties, license fees, and other services, such as communication, construction, financial, information, business, personal, and government services. They exclude compensation of employees and investment income (formerly called factor services) and transfer payments. Data are in current US$, millions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Exports GNFS, current LCU, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Exports of goods and services represent the value of all goods and other market services provided to the rest of the world. They include the value of merchandise, freight, insurance, transport, travel, royalties, license fees, and other services, such as communication, construction, financial, information, business, personal, and government services. They exclude compensation of employees and investment income (formerly called factor services) and transfer payments. Data are in current LCU, millions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Exports GNFS, constant US$, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Exports of goods and services represent the value of all goods and other market services provided to the rest of the world. They include the value of merchandise, freight, insurance, transport, travel, royalties, license fees, and other services, such as communication, construction, financial, information, business, personal, and government services. They exclude compensation of employees and investment income (formerly called factor services) and transfer payments. Data are in constant US$, millions. The base year is 2005.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Exports GNFS, constant LCU, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Exports of goods and services represent the value of all goods and other market services provided to the rest of the world. They include the value of merchandise, freight, insurance, transport, travel, royalties, license fees, and other services, such as communication, construction, financial, information, business, personal, and government services. They exclude compensation of employees and investment income (formerly called factor services) and transfer payments. Data are in constant LCU, millions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Exports, GNFS (implicit price deflator constant 2005 USD)
Exports GNFS deflator, LCU
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The Exports GNFS implicit deflator is the ratio of Exports GNFS in current local currency to Exports GNFS in constant local currency. The base year varies by country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross Domestic Expenditure (GDE) (real local currency units, various base years)
Fixed Investment, current US$, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Fixed investment includes land improvements (fences, ditches, drains, and so on); plant, machinery, and equipment purchases; and the construction of roads, railways, and the like, including schools, offices, hospitals, private residential dwellings, and commercial and industrial buildings. According to the 1993 SNA, net acquisitions of valuables are also considered capital formation. Data are in current US$ millions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Fixed Investment, current LCU, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Fixed investment includes land improvements (fences, ditches, drains, and so on); plant, machinery, and equipment purchases; and the construction of roads, railways, and the like, including schools, offices, hospitals, private residential dwellings, and commercial and industrial buildings. According to the 1993 SNA, net acquisitions of valuables are also considered capital formation. Data are in current LCU millions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Fixed Investment, constant US$, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Fixed investment includes land improvements (fences, ditches, drains, and so on); plant, machinery, and equipment purchases; and the construction of roads, railways, and the like, including schools, offices, hospitals, private residential dwellings, and commercial and industrial buildings. According to the 1993 SNA, net acquisitions of valuables are also considered capital formation. Data are in constant US$ millions. The base year is 2005.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Fixed Investment, constant LCU, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Fixed investment includes land improvements (fences, ditches, drains, and so on); plant, machinery, and equipment purchases; and the construction of roads, railways, and the like, including schools, offices, hospitals, private residential dwellings, and commercial and industrial buildings. According to the 1993 SNA, net acquisitions of valuables are also considered capital formation. Data are in constant LCU millions. The base year varies by country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross Fixed Investment (implicit price deflator constant 2005 USD)
Fixed Investment deflator, LCU
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The Fixed Investment implicit deflator is the ratio of Fixed Investment in current local currency to Fixed Investment in constant local currency. The base year varies by country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Estimated Capital stock (real local currency units, various base years)
Change in Inventories, current US$, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Inventories are stocks of goods held by firms to meet temporary or unexpected fluctuations in production or sales, and "work in progress." Data is in current US$, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Change in Inventories, current LCU, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Inventories are stocks of goods held by firms to meet temporary or unexpected fluctuations in production or sales, and "work in progress." Data is in curent LCU, millions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Change in Inventories, constant US$, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Inventories are stocks of goods held by firms to meet temporary or unexpected fluctuations in production or sales, and "work in progress." Data is in constant US$ millions. The base year is 2005.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Change in Inventories, constant LCU, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Inventories are stocks of goods held by firms to meet temporary or unexpected fluctuations in production or sales, and "work in progress." Data is in constant LCU, millions. The base year varies by country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Change in Inventories deflator, LCU
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The Change in Inventories implicit deflator is the ratio of Change in Inventories in current local currency to Change in Inventories in constant local currency. The base year varies by country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total Investment, current US$, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total Investment consists of outlays on additions to the fixed assets of the economy plus net changes in the level of inventories. Fixed assets include land improvements (fences, ditches, drains, and so on); plant, machinery, and equipment purchases; and the construction of roads, railways, and the like, including schools, offices, hospitals, private residential dwellings, and commercial and industrial buildings. Inventories are stocks of goods held by firms to meet temporary or unexpected fluctuations in production or sales, and "work in progress." According to the 1993 SNA, net acquisitions of valuables are also considered capital formation. Data are in current US$ millions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total Investment, current LCU, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total Investment consists of outlays on additions to the fixed assets of the economy plus net changes in the level of inventories. Fixed assets include land improvements (fences, ditches, drains, and so on); plant, machinery, and equipment purchases; and the construction of roads, railways, and the like, including schools, offices, hospitals, private residential dwellings, and commercial and industrial buildings. Inventories are stocks of goods held by firms to meet temporary or unexpected fluctuations in production or sales, and "work in progress." According to the 1993 SNA, net acquisitions of valuables are also considered capital formation. Data are in current LCU millions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total Investment, constant US$, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total Investment consists of outlays on additions to the fixed assets of the economy plus net changes in the level of inventories. Fixed assets include land improvements (fences, ditches, drains, and so on); plant, machinery, and equipment purchases; and the construction of roads, railways, and the like, including schools, offices, hospitals, private residential dwellings, and commercial and industrial buildings. Inventories are stocks of goods held by firms to meet temporary or unexpected fluctuations in production or sales, and "work in progress." According to the 1993 SNA, net acquisitions of valuables are also considered capital formation. Data are in constant US$ millions. The base year is 2005.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total Investment, constant LCU, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total Investment consists of outlays on additions to the fixed assets of the economy plus net changes in the level of inventories. Fixed assets include land improvements (fences, ditches, drains, and so on); plant, machinery, and equipment purchases; and the construction of roads, railways, and the like, including schools, offices, hospitals, private residential dwellings, and commercial and industrial buildings. Inventories are stocks of goods held by firms to meet temporary or unexpected fluctuations in production or sales, and "work in progress." According to the 1993 SNA, net acquisitions of valuables are also considered capital formation. Data are in constant LCU millions. The base year varies by country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total Investment deflator, LCU
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The Total Investment implicit deflator is the ratio of Total Invesment in current local currency to Total Investment in constant local currency. The base year varies by country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Imports GNFS, current US$, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Imports of goods and services represent the value of all goods and other market services received from the rest of the world. They include the value of merchandise, freight, insurance, transport, travel, royalties, license fees, and other services, such as communication, construction, financial, information, business, personal, and government services. They exclude compensation of employees and investment income (formerly called factor services) and transfer payments. Data are in current US$, millions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Imports GNFS, current LCU, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Imports of goods and services represent the value of all goods and other market services received from the rest of the world. They include the value of merchandise, freight, insurance, transport, travel, royalties, license fees, and other services, such as communication, construction, financial, information, business, personal, and government services. They exclude compensation of employees and investment income (formerly called factor services) and transfer payments. Data are in current LCU, millions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Imports GNFS, constant US$, millions

They include the value of merchandise, freight, insurance, transport, travel, royalties, license fees, and other services, such as communication, construction, financial, information, business, personal, and government services. They exclude compensation of employees and investment income (formerly called factor services) and transfer payments. Data are in constant US$, millions. The base year is 2005.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Imports GNFS, constant LCU, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Imports of goods and services represent the value of all goods and other market services received from the rest of the world. They include the value of merchandise, freight, insurance, transport, travel, royalties, license fees, and other services, such as communication, construction, financial, information, business, personal, and government services. They exclude compensation of employees and investment income (formerly called factor services) and transfer payments. Data are in constant LCU, millions. The base year varies by country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Imports, GNFS (implicit price deflator constant 2005 USD)
Imports GNFS deflator, LCU
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The Imports GNFS implicit deflator is the ratio of Imports GNFS in current local currency to Imports GNFS in constant local currency. The base year varies by country.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Natural gas, Europe, $/mmbtu, current$
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Natural Gas (Europe), average import border price, including UK. As of April 2010 includes a spot price component. Between June 2000 - March 2010 excludes UK
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Gas Intelligence; World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Natural gas LNG, $/mmbtu, current$
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Natural gas LNG (Japan), import price, cif, recent two months' averages are estimates.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Gas Intelligence; World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Natural gas, US, $/mmbtu, current$
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Natural Gas (U.S.), spot price at Henry Hub, Louisiana
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Thomson Reuters Datastream; The Wall Street Journal; World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Nickel, $/mt, current$
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Nickel (LME), cathodes, minimum 99.8% purity, settlement price beginning 2005; previously cash price
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Platts Metals Week, Thomson Reuters Datastream; World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Real agricultural GDP per capita growth rate (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The growth rate of real per capita GDP in agriculture, expressed at an annual rate.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Agriculture, value added (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Agriculture corresponds to ISIC divisions 1-5 and includes forestry, hunting, and fishing, as well as cultivation of crops and livestock production. Value added is the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or depletion and degradation of natural resources. The origin of value added is determined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), revision 3. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Agriculture, value added (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Agriculture corresponds to ISIC divisions 1-5 and includes forestry, hunting, and fishing, as well as cultivation of crops and livestock production. Value added is the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or depletion and degradation of natural resources. The origin of value added is determined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), revision 3. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Agriculture, value added (constant 2005 US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Agriculture corresponds to ISIC divisions 1-5 and includes forestry, hunting, and fishing, as well as cultivation of crops and livestock production. Value added is the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or depletion and degradation of natural resources. The origin of value added is determined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), revision 3. Data are in constant 2005 U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Agriculture, value added (annual % growth)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Annual growth rate for agricultural value added based on constant local currency. Aggregates are based on constant 2005 U.S. dollars. Agriculture corresponds to ISIC divisions 1-5 and includes forestry, hunting, and fishing, as well as cultivation of crops and livestock production. Value added is the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or depletion and degradation of natural resources. The origin of value added is determined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), revision 3.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Agriculture, value added (constant LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Agriculture corresponds to ISIC divisions 1-5 and includes forestry, hunting, and fishing, as well as cultivation of crops and livestock production. Value added is the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or depletion and degradation of natural resources. The origin of value added is determined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), revision 3. Data are in constant local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Real agricultural GDP growth rates (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: This is the annual rate of growth of agricultural GDP. Value added in agriculture measures the output of the agricultural sector (ISIC divisions 1-5) less the value of intermediate inputs. Agriculture comprises value added from forestry, hunting, and fishing as well as cultivation of crops and livestock production. Value added is the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or depletion and degradation of natural resources. The industrial origin of value added is determined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), revision 2. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Agriculture, value added (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Agriculture corresponds to ISIC divisions 1-5 and includes forestry, hunting, and fishing, as well as cultivation of crops and livestock production. Value added is the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or depletion and degradation of natural resources. The origin of value added is determined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), revision 3. Note: For VAB countries, gross value added at factor cost is used as the denominator.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Construction, value added (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Value added in construction is defined as the value of output of the construction industry less the value of intermediate consumption (intermediate inputs). Construction is a subset of industry (ISIC 45). Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Construction, value added (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Value added in construction is defined as the value of output of the construction industry less the value of intermediate consumption (intermediate inputs). Construction is a subset of industry (ISIC 45). Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Construction, value added (constant LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Value added in construction is defined as the value of output of the construction industry less the value of intermediate consumption (intermediate inputs). Construction is a subset of industry (ISIC 45). Data are in constant local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gas, electricity and water, value added (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Value added in gas, electricity and water is defined as the value of output of the ‘Electricity, Gas and Water supply' industry less the value of intermediate consumption (intermediate inputs). Gas, electricity and water is a subset of industry (ISIC 40-41). Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gas, electricity and water, value added (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Value added in gas, electricity and water is defined as the value of output of the ‘Electricity, Gas and Water supply' industry less the value of intermediate consumption (intermediate inputs). Gas, electricity and water is a subset of industry (ISIC 40-41). Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gas, electricity and water, value added (constant LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Value added in gas, electricity and water is defined as the value of output of the ‘Electricity, Gas and Water supply' industry less the value of intermediate consumption (intermediate inputs). Gas, electricity and water is a subset of industry (ISIC 40-41). Data are in constant local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Manufacturing, value added (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Manufacturing refers to industries belonging to ISIC divisions 15-37. Value added is the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or depletion and degradation of natural resources. The origin of value added is determined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), revision 3. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Manufacturing, value added (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Manufacturing refers to industries belonging to ISIC divisions 15-37. Value added is the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or depletion and degradation of natural resources. The origin of value added is determined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), revision 3. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Manufacturing, value added (constant 2005 US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Manufacturing refers to industries belonging to ISIC divisions 15-37. Value added is the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or depletion and degradation of natural resources. The origin of value added is determined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), revision 3. Data are expressed constant 2005 U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Manufacturing, value added (annual % growth)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Annual growth rate for manufacturing value added based on constant local currency. Aggregates are based on constant 2005 U.S. dollars. Manufacturing refers to industries belonging to ISIC divisions 15-37. Value added is the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or depletion and degradation of natural resources. The origin of value added is determined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), revision 3.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Manufacturing, value added (constant LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Manufacturing refers to industries belonging to ISIC divisions 15-37. Value added is the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or depletion and degradation of natural resources. The origin of value added is determined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), revision 3. Data are in constant local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Value added, manufacturing growth rate (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: This is the annual rate of growth of value added in manufacturing. Manufacturing refers to industries belonging to ISIC divisions 15-37. Value added is the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or depletion and degradation of natural resources. The industrial origin of value added is determined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), revision 2.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Manufacturing, value added (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Manufacturing refers to industries belonging to ISIC divisions 15-37. Value added is the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or depletion and degradation of natural resources. The origin of value added is determined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), revision 3. Note: For VAB countries, gross value added at factor cost is used as the denominator.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Mining and quarrying, value added (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Value added in mining and quarrying is defined as the value of output of the mining and quarrying industries less the value of intermediate consumption (intermediate inputs). Mining and quarrying is a subset of industry (ISIC 10-14). Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Mining and quarrying, value added (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Value added in mining and quarrying is defined as the value of output of the mining and quarrying industries less the value of intermediate consumption (intermediate inputs). Mining and quarrying is a subset of industry (ISIC 10-14). Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Value added, mining and quarrying (constant 2000 US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Value added in mining and quarrying is defined as the value of output of the mining and quarrying industries less the value of intermediate consumption (intermediate inputs). Mining and quarrying is a subset of industry (ISIC 10-14). Data are in constant 2000 U.S. dollars.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Mining and quarrying, value added (constant LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Value added in mining and quarrying is defined as the value of output of the mining and quarrying industries less the value of intermediate consumption (intermediate inputs). Mining and quarrying is a subset of industry (ISIC 10-14). Data are in constant local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Industry, value added (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Industry corresponds to ISIC divisions 10-45 and includes manufacturing (ISIC divisions 15-37). It comprises value added in mining, manufacturing (also reported as a separate subgroup), construction, electricity, water, and gas. Value added is the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or depletion and degradation of natural resources. The origin of value added is determined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), revision 3. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Industry, value added (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Industry corresponds to ISIC divisions 10-45 and includes manufacturing (ISIC divisions 15-37). The origin of value added is determined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), revision 3. Data are in current local currency.

Value added is the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. The origin of value added is determined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), revision 3.

It comprises value added in mining, manufacturing (also reported as a separate subgroup), construction, electricity, water, and gas. Value added is the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or depletion and degradation of natural resources. The origin of value added is determined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), revision 3. Data are in constant local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Industry, value added (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Industry corresponds to ISIC divisions 10-45 and includes manufacturing (ISIC divisions 15-37). It comprises value added in mining, manufacturing (also reported as a separate subgroup), construction, electricity, water, and gas. Value added is the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or depletion and degradation of natural resources. The origin of value added is determined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), revision 3. Note: For VAB countries, gross value added at factor cost is used as the denominator.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Chemicals (% of value added in manufacturing)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Value added in manufacturing is the sum of gross output less the value of intermediate inputs used in production for industries classified in ISIC major division D. Chemicals correspond to ISIC division 24.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Industrial Development Organization, International Yearbook of Industrial Statistics.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Food, beverages and tobacco (% of value added in manufacturing)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Value added in manufacturing is the sum of gross output less the value of intermediate inputs used in production for industries classified in ISIC major division D. Food, beverages, and tobacco correspond to ISIC divisions 15 and 16.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Industrial Development Organization, International Yearbook of Industrial Statistics.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Machinery and transport equipment (% of value added in manufacturing)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Value added in manufacturing is the sum of gross output less the value of intermediate inputs used in production for industries classified in ISIC major division D. Machinery and transport equipment correspond to ISIC divisions 29, 30, 32, 34, and 35.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Industrial Development Organization, International Yearbook of Industrial Statistics.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Other manufacturing (% of value added in manufacturing)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Value added in manufacturing is the sum of gross output less the value of intermediate inputs used in production for industries classified in ISIC major division D. Other manufacturing, a residual, covers wood and related products (ISIC division 20), paper and related products (ISIC divisions 21 and 22), petroleum and related products (ISIC division 23), basic metals and mineral products (ISIC division27), fabricated metal products and professional goods (ISIC division 28), and other industries (ISIC divisions 25, 26, 31, 33, 36, and 37). Includes unallocated data. When data for textiles, machinery, or chemicals are shown as not available, they are included in other manufacturing.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Industrial Development Organization, International Yearbook of Industrial Statistics.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Textiles and clothing (% of value added in manufacturing)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Value added in manufacturing is the sum of gross output less the value of intermediate inputs used in production for industries classified in ISIC major division D. Textiles and clothing correspond to ISIC divisions 17-19.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Industrial Development Organization, International Yearbook of Industrial Statistics.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Public administration and defense, value added (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Value added in public administration and defense is defined as the value of output of the public administration and defense industries less the value of intermediate consumption (intermediate inputs). Public administration and defense is a subset of services (ISIC 75). Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Public administration and defense, value added (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Value added in public administration and defense is defined as the value of output of the public administration and defense industries less the value of intermediate consumption (intermediate inputs). Public administration and defense is a subset of services (ISIC 75). Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Public administration and defense, value added (constant LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Value added in public administration and defense is defined as the value of output of the public administration and defense industries less the value of intermediate consumption (intermediate inputs). Public administration and defense is a subset of services (ISIC 75). Data are in constant local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Banking, value added (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Value added in banking is defined as the value of output of the banking industry less the value of intermediate consumption (intermediate inputs). Banking is a subset of services, comprising financial intermediation (ISIC 65-67). Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Banking, value added (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Value added in banking is defined as the value of output of the banking industry less the value of intermediate consumption (intermediate inputs). Banking is a subset of services, comprising financial intermediation (ISIC 65-67). Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Banking, value added (constant LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Value added in banking is defined as the value of output of the banking industry less the value of intermediate consumption (intermediate inputs). Banking is a subset of services, comprising financial intermediation (ISIC 65-67). Data are in constant local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Discrepancy in GDP, value added (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: This is the discrepancy included in the value added of services, etc. Covered here are any discrepancies noted by national compilers as well as discrepancies arising from linking new and old series in the World Bank data base. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Discrepancy in GDP, value added (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: This is the discrepancy included in the value added of services, etc. Covered here are any discrepancies noted by national compilers as well as discrepancies arising from linking new and old series in the World Bank data base. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Discrepancy in GDP, value added (constant LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: This is the discrepancy included in the value added of services, etc. Covered here are any discrepancies noted by national compilers as well as discrepancies arising from linking new and old series in the World Bank data base. Data are in constant local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Ownership of dwellings, value added (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Value added in dwellings is defined as the imputed value of output of owner occupied dwellings less the value of intermediate consumption (intermediate inputs). Dwellings is a subset of services (part of ISIC 70). Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Ownership of dwellings, value added (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Value added in dwellings is defined as the imputed value of output of owner occupied dwellings less the value of intermediate consumption (intermediate inputs). Dwellings is a subset of services (part of ISIC 70). Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Ownership of dwellings, value added (constant LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Value added in dwellings is defined as the imputed value of output of owner occupied dwellings less the value of intermediate consumption (intermediate inputs). Dwellings is a subset of services (part of ISIC 70). Data are in constant local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Other services, value added (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Value added in other services is defined as the value of output of the 'other services' industry less the value of intermediate consumption (intermediate inputs). Other services is a subset of services, comprising real estate, renting and business activities (excluding services of owner occupied dwellings), education, health and social work, other community, social and personal service activities, private households with employed persons, and extra territorial organizations (ISIC 70-74, 80-99). Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Other services, value added (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Value added in other services is defined as the value of output of the 'other services' industry less the value of intermediate consumption (intermediate inputs). Other services is a subset of services, comprising real estate, renting and business activities (excluding services of owner occupied dwellings), education, health and social work, other community, social and personal service activities, private households with employed persons, and extra territorial organizations (ISIC 70-74, 80-99). Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Other services, value added (constant LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Value added in other services is defined as the value of output of the 'other services' industry less the value of intermediate consumption (intermediate inputs). Other services is a subset of services, comprising real estate, renting and business activities (excluding services of owner occupied dwellings), education, health and social work, other community, social and personal service activities, private households with employed persons, and extra territorial organizations (ISIC 70-74, 80-99). Data are in constant local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Services, etc., value added (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Services correspond to ISIC divisions 50-99. They include value added in wholesale and retail trade (including hotels and restaurants), transport, and government, financial, professional, and personal services such as education, health care, and real estate services. Also included are imputed bank service charges, import duties, and any statistical discrepancies noted by national compilers as well as discrepancies arising from rescaling. Value added is the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or depletion and degradation of natural resources. The industrial origin of value added is determined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), revision 3. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Services, etc., value added (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Services correspond to ISIC divisions 50-99. They include value added in wholesale and retail trade (including hotels and restaurants), transport, and government, financial, professional, and personal services such as education, health care, and real estate services. Also included are imputed bank service charges, import duties, and any statistical discrepancies noted by national compilers as well as discrepancies arising from rescaling. Value added is the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or depletion and degradation of natural resources. The industrial origin of value added is determined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), revision 3. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

Also included are imputed bank service charges, import duties, and any statistical discrepancies noted by national compilers as well as discrepancies arising from rescaling. wb:indicator.wb:name: Services, value added (current US$)

Also included are imputed bank service charges and import duties. Value added is the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. wb:indicator.wb:name: Services, value added (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Services correspond to ISIC divisions 50-99. They include value added in wholesale and retail trade (including hotels and restaurants), transport, and government, financial, professional, and personal services such as education, health care, and real estate services. Also included are imputed bank service charges and import duties. Value added is the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or depletion and degradation of natural resources. The industrial origin of value added is determined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), revision 2. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Value added, services (constant 2000 US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Value added (gross) in ‘Services’ is defined as the value of output of the ‘Service’ industry less the value of intermediate consumption (intermediate inputs). ‘Services’ comprises wholesale and retail trade, hotel and restaurants, transport, storage and communications, financial intermediation, real estate, renting and business activities, public administration and defense, education, health and social work, other community, social and personal service activities, private households with employed persons, and extra-territorial organizations (ISIC 50-99). Data are in constant 2000 U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Services, value added (constant LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Services correspond to ISIC divisions 50-99. They include value added in wholesale and retail trade (including hotels and restaurants), transport, and government, financial, professional, and personal services such as education, health care, and real estate services. Also included are imputed bank service charges and import duties. Value added is the net output of a sector after adding up all outputs and subtracting intermediate inputs. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or depletion and degradation of natural resources. The industrial origin of value added is determined by the International Standard Industrial Classification (ISIC), revision 2. Data are in constant local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Wholesale and retail trade, value added (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Value added in trade is defined as the value of output of the trade industry less the value of intermediate consumption (intermediate inputs). Trade is a subset of services, comprising wholesale and retail trade, and hotel and restaurants (ISIC 50-55). Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Wholesale and retail trade, value added (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Value added in trade is defined as the value of output of the trade industry less the value of intermediate consumption (intermediate inputs). Trade is a subset of services, comprising wholesale and retail trade, and hotel and restaurants (ISIC 50-55). Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Wholesale and retail trade, value added (constant LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Value added in trade is defined as the value of output of the trade industry less the value of intermediate consumption (intermediate inputs). Trade is a subset of services, comprising wholesale and retail trade, and hotel and restaurants (ISIC 50-55). Data are in constant local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Transport, storage and communication, value added (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Value added in transport is defined as the value of output of the transport industry less the value of intermediate consumption (intermediate inputs). Transport is a subset of services, comprising transport, storage and communications (ISIC 60-64). Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Transport, storage and communication, value added (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Value added in transport is defined as the value of output of the transport industry less the value of intermediate consumption (intermediate inputs). Transport is a subset of services, comprising transport, storage and communications (ISIC 60-64). Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Transport, storage and communication, value added (constant LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Value added in transport is defined as the value of output of the transport industry less the value of intermediate consumption (intermediate inputs). Transport is a subset of services, comprising transport, storage and communications (ISIC 60-64). Data are in constant local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Adjusted savings: education expenditure (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Education expenditure refers to the current operating expenditures in education, including wages and salaries and excluding capital investments in buildings and equipment.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates using data from the United Nations Statistics Division's Statistical Yearbook, and the UNESCO Institute for Statistics online database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Adjusted savings: education expenditure (% of GNI)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Education expenditure refers to the current operating expenditures in education, including wages and salaries and excluding capital investments in buildings and equipment.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates using data from the United Nations Statistics Division's Statistical Yearbook, and the UNESCO Institute for Statistics online database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Adjusted savings: carbon dioxide damage (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Carbon dioxide damage is estimated to be $20 per ton of carbon (the unit damage in 1995 U.S. dollars) times the number of tons of carbon emitted.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based on Samuel Fankhauser's "Valuing Climate Change: The Economics of the Greenhouse" (1995).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Adjusted savings: carbon dioxide damage (% of GNI)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Carbon dioxide damage is estimated to be $20 per ton of carbon (the unit damage in 1995 U.S. dollars) times the number of tons of carbon emitted.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based on Samuel Fankhauser's "Valuing Climate Change: The Economics of the Greenhouse" (1995).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Adjusted savings: net forest depletion (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net forest depletion is calculated as the product of unit resource rents and the excess of roundwood harvest over natural growth.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods in World Bank's "The Changing Wealth of Nations: Measuring Sustainable Development in the New Millennium" (2011).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Adjusted savings: net forest depletion (% of GNI)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net forest depletion is calculated as the product of unit resource rents and the excess of roundwood harvest over natural growth.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods in World Bank's "The Changing Wealth of Nations: Measuring Sustainable Development in the New Millennium" (2011).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Adjusted savings: consumption of fixed capital (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Consumption of fixed capital represents the replacement value of capital used up in the process of production.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates using data from the United Nations Statistics Division's National Accounts Statistics.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Adjusted savings: consumption of fixed capital (% of GNI)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Consumption of fixed capital represents the replacement value of capital used up in the process of production.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates using data from the United Nations Statistics Division's National Accounts Statistics.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Adjusted savings: mineral depletion (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Mineral depletion is the ratio of the value of the stock of mineral resources to the remaining reserve lifetime (capped at 25 years). It covers tin, gold, lead, zinc, iron, copper, nickel, silver, bauxite, and phosphate.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods in World Bank's "The Changing Wealth of Nations: Measuring Sustainable Development in the New Millennium" (2011).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Adjusted savings: mineral depletion (% of GNI)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Mineral depletion is the ratio of the value of the stock of mineral resources to the remaining reserve lifetime (capped at 25 years). It covers tin, gold, lead, zinc, iron, copper, nickel, silver, bauxite, and phosphate.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods in World Bank's "The Changing Wealth of Nations: Measuring Sustainable Development in the New Millennium" (2011).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Adjusted savings: energy depletion (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Energy depletion is the ratio of the value of the stock of energy resources to the remaining reserve lifetime (capped at 25 years). It covers coal, crude oil, and natural gas.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods in World Bank's "The Changing Wealth of Nations: Measuring Sustainable Development in the New Millennium" (2011).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Adjusted savings: energy depletion (% of GNI)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Energy depletion is the ratio of the value of the stock of energy resources to the remaining reserve lifetime (capped at 25 years). It covers coal, crude oil, and natural gas.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods in World Bank's "The Changing Wealth of Nations: Measuring Sustainable Development in the New Millennium" (2011).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Adjusted savings: particulate emission damage (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Particulate emissions damage is calculated as the willingness to pay to avoid mortality attributable to particulate emissions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Kiran D. Pandey and others' "The Human Costs of Air Pollution: New Estimates for Developing Countries" (working paper).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Adjusted savings: particulate emission damage (% of GNI)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Particulate emissions damage is calculated as the willingness to pay to avoid mortality attributable to particulate emissions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Kiran D. Pandey and others' "The Human Costs of Air Pollution: New Estimates for Developing Countries" (working paper).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Adjusted savings: natural resources depletion (% of GNI)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Natural resource depletion is the sum of net forest depletion, energy depletion, and mineral depletion. Net forest depletion is unit resource rents times the excess of roundwood harvest over natural growth. Energy depletion is the ratio of the value of the stock of energy resources to the remaining reserve lifetime (capped at 25 years). It covers coal, crude oil, and natural gas. Mineral depletion is the ratio of the value of the stock of mineral resources to the remaining reserve lifetime (capped at 25 years). It covers tin, gold, lead, zinc, iron, copper, nickel, silver, bauxite, and phosphate.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods in World Bank's "The Changing Wealth of Nations: Measuring Sustainable Development in the New Millennium" (2011).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Adjusted savings: gross savings (% of GNI)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross savings are the difference between gross national income and public and private consumption, plus net current transfers.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Adjusted savings: net national savings (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net national savings are equal to gross national savings less the value of consumption of fixed capital.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods in World Bank's "The Changing Wealth of Nations: Measuring Sustainable Development in the New Millennium" (2011).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Adjusted savings: net national savings (% of GNI)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net national savings are equal to gross national savings less the value of consumption of fixed capital.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods in World Bank's "The Changing Wealth of Nations: Measuring Sustainable Development in the New Millennium" (2011).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Adjusted net national income (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Adjusted net national income is GNI minus consumption of fixed capital and natural resources depletion.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods in World Bank's "The Changing Wealth of Nations: Measuring Sustainable Development in the New Millennium" (2011).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Adjusted net national income (constant 2005 US$)
