wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Adjusted net national income is GNI minus consumption of fixed capital and natural resources depletion.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods in World Bank's "The Changing Wealth of Nations: Measuring Sustainable Development in the New Millennium" (2011).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Adjusted net national income (annual % growth)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Adjusted net national income is GNI minus consumption of fixed capital and natural resources depletion.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods in World Bank's "The Changing Wealth of Nations: Measuring Sustainable Development in the New Millennium" (2011).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Adjusted net national income per capita (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Adjusted net national income is GNI minus consumption of fixed capital and natural resources depletion.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods in World Bank's "The Changing Wealth of Nations: Measuring Sustainable Development in the New Millennium" (2011).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Adjusted net savings, including particulate emission damage (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Adjusted net savings are equal to net national savings plus education expenditure and minus energy depletion, mineral depletion, net forest depletion, and carbon dioxide and particulate emissions damage.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods in World Bank's "The Changing Wealth of Nations: Measuring Sustainable Development in the New Millennium" (2011).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Adjusted net savings, including particulate emission damage (% of GNI)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Adjusted net savings are equal to net national savings plus education expenditure and minus energy depletion, mineral depletion, net forest depletion, and carbon dioxide and particulate emissions damage.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods in World Bank's "The Changing Wealth of Nations: Measuring Sustainable Development in the New Millennium" (2011).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Adjusted net savings, excluding particulate emission damage (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Adjusted net savings are equal to net national savings plus education expenditure and minus energy depletion, mineral depletion, net forest depletion, and carbon dioxide. This series excludes particulate emissions damage.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods in World Bank's "The Changing Wealth of Nations: Measuring Sustainable Development in the New Millennium" (2011).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Adjusted net savings, excluding particulate emission damage (% of GNI)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Adjusted net savings are equal to net national savings plus education expenditure and minus energy depletion, mineral depletion, net forest depletion, and carbon dioxide. This series excludes particulate emissions damage.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods in World Bank's "The Changing Wealth of Nations: Measuring Sustainable Development in the New Millennium" (2011).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Agricultural support estimate (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Agriculture support is the annual monetary value of all gross transfers from taxpayers and consumers, both domestic and foreign (in the form of subsidies arising from policy measures that support agriculture), net of the associated budgetary receipts, regardless of their objectives and impacts on farm production and income, or consumption of farm products.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, Producer and Consumer Support Estimates database. Available online at www.oecd.org/tad/support/psecse.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Exports as a capacity to import (constant LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Exports as a capacity to import equals the current price value of exports of goods and services deflated by the import price index. Data are in constant local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Coal rents (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Coal rents are the difference between the value of both hard and soft coal production at world prices and their total costs of production.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Estimates based on sources and methods described in "The Changing Wealth of Nations: Measuring Sustainable Development in the New Millennium" (World Bank, 2011).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Inflation, GDP deflator (annual %)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Inflation as measured by the annual growth rate of the GDP implicit deflator shows the rate of price change in the economy as a whole. The GDP implicit deflator is the ratio of GDP in current local currency to GDP in constant local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GDP deflator (base year varies by country)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The GDP implicit deflator is the ratio of GDP in current local currency to GDP in constant local currency. The base year varies by country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Discrepancy in expenditure estimate of GDP (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: This is the discrepancy included in the ‘total consumption etc.' This discrepancy is included to ensures that GDP from the expenditure side equals GDP measured by the income or output approach. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Discrepancy in expenditure estimate of GDP (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Discrepancy in expenditure estimate of GDP is the discrepancy included in final consumption expenditure, etc. (total consumption, etc.). This discrepancy is included to ensure that GDP from the expenditure side equals GDP measured by the income or output approach. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Discrepancy in expenditure estimate of GDP (constant LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: A statistical discrepancy usually arises when the GDP components are estimated independently by industrial origin and by expenditure categories. This item represents the discrepancy in the use of resources (i.e., the estimate of GDP by expenditure categories). Data are in constant local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross value added at factor cost (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross value added at factor cost (formerly GDP at factor cost) is derived as the sum of the value added in the agriculture, industry and services sectors. If the value added of these sectors is calculated at purchaser values, gross value added at factor cost is derived by subtracting net product taxes from GDP. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross value added at factor cost (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross value added at factor cost (formerly GDP at factor cost) is derived as the sum of the value added in the agriculture, industry and services sectors. If the value added of these sectors is calculated at purchaser values, gross value added at factor cost is derived by subtracting net product taxes from GDP. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross value added at factor cost (constant 2005 US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross value added at factor cost (formerly GDP at factor cost) is derived as the sum of the value added in the agriculture, industry and services sectors. If the value added of these sectors is calculated at purchaser values, gross value added at factor cost is derived by subtracting net product taxes from GDP. Data are in constant 2005 U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross value added at factor cost (constant LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross value added at factor cost (formerly GDP at factor cost) is derived as the sum of the value added in the agriculture, industry and services sectors. If the value added of these sectors is calculated at purchaser values, gross value added at factor cost is derived by subtracting net product taxes from GDP. Data are in constant local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Forest rents (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Forest rents are roundwood harvest times the product of average prices and a region-specific rental rate.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Estimates based on sources and methods described in "The Changing Wealth of Nations: Measuring Sustainable Development in the New Millennium" (World Bank, 2011).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Mineral rents (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Mineral rents are the difference between the value of production for a stock of minerals at world prices and their total costs of production. Minerals included in the calculation are tin, gold, lead, zinc, iron, copper, nickel, silver, bauxite, and phosphate.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Estimates based on sources and methods described in "The Changing Wealth of Nations: Measuring Sustainable Development in the New Millennium" (World Bank, 2011).

wb:indicator.wb:name: GDP (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: GDP at purchaser's prices is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in current U.S. dollars. Dollar figures for GDP are converted from domestic currencies using single year official exchange rates. For a few countries where the official exchange rate does not reflect the rate effectively applied to actual foreign exchange transactions, an alternative conversion factor is used.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GDP deflator, index (2000=100; US$ series)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The GDP deflator series based upon the U.S. dollar series is defined as the ratio of the GDP at market prices in current U.S. dollars) to the GDP at market prices in constant (2000) U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GDP (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: GDP at purchaser's prices is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GDP deflator, period average (LCU index 2000=100)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The GDP implicit deflator is the ratio of GDP in current local currency to GDP in constant local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GDP (constant 2005 US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: GDP at purchaser's prices is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in constant 2005 U.S. dollars. Dollar figures for GDP are converted from domestic currencies using 2000 official exchange rates. For a few countries where the official exchange rate does not reflect the rate effectively applied to actual foreign exchange transactions, an alternative conversion factor is used.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GDP growth (annual %)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Annual percentage growth rate of GDP at market prices based on constant local currency. Aggregates are based on constant 2005 U.S. dollars. GDP is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GDP growth (annual%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: GDP growth (annual%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GDP (constant LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: GDP is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in constant local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GDP, PPP (current international $)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: PPP GDP is gross domestic product converted to international dollars using purchasing power parity rates. An international dollar has the same purchasing power over GDP as the U.S. dollar has in the United States. GDP is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in current international dollars. For most economies PPP figures are extrapolated from the 2011 International Comparison Program (ICP) benchmark estimates or imputed using a statistical model based on the 2011 ICP. For 47 high- and upper middle-income economies conversion factors are provided by Eurostat and the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, International Comparison Program database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GDP, PPP (constant 2011 international $)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: PPP GDP is gross domestic product converted to international dollars using purchasing power parity rates. An international dollar has the same purchasing power over GDP as the U.S. dollar has in the United States. GDP is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in constant 2011 international dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, International Comparison Program database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GDP deflator, end period (base year varies by country)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The GDP implicit deflator is the ratio of GDP in current local currency to GDP in constant local currency. The base year varies by country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Natural gas rents (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Natural gas rents are the difference between the value of natural gas production at world prices and total costs of production.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Estimates based on sources and methods described in "The Changing Wealth of Nations: Measuring Sustainable Development in the New Millennium" (World Bank, 2011).

wb:indicator.wb:name: GDP per capita (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: GDP per capita is gross domestic product divided by midyear population. GDP is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GDP per capita (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: GDP per capita is gross domestic product divided by midyear population. GDP is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GDP per capita (constant 2005 US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: GDP per capita is gross domestic product divided by midyear population. GDP is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in constant 2005 U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GDP per capita growth (annual %)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Annual percentage growth rate of GDP per capita based on constant local currency. Aggregates are based on constant 2005 U.S. dollars. GDP per capita is gross domestic product divided by midyear population. GDP at purchaser's prices is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GDP per capita (constant LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: GDP per capita is gross domestic product divided by midyear population. GDP at purchaser's prices is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in constant local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GDP per capita, PPP (current international $)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: GDP per capita based on purchasing power parity (PPP). PPP GDP is gross domestic product converted to international dollars using purchasing power parity rates. An international dollar has the same purchasing power over GDP as the U.S. dollar has in the United States. GDP at purchaser's prices is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in current international dollars based on the 2011 ICP round.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, International Comparison Program database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GDP per capita, PPP (constant 2011 international $)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: GDP per capita based on purchasing power parity (PPP). PPP GDP is gross domestic product converted to international dollars using purchasing power parity rates. An international dollar has the same purchasing power over GDP as the U.S. dollar has in the United States. GDP at purchaser's prices is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in constant 2011 international dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, International Comparison Program database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GDP per capita, PPP annual growth (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Annual percentage growth rate of GDP per capita based on purchasing power parity (PPP). GDP per capita based on purchasing power parity (PPP). PPP GDP is gross domestic product converted to international dollars using purchasing power parity rates. An international dollar has the same purchasing power over GDP as the U.S. dollar has in the United States. GDP at purchaser's prices is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in constant 2000 international dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: "World Bank, International Comparison Programme database. "

wb:indicator.wb:name: Oil rents (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Oil rents are the difference between the value of crude oil production at world prices and total costs of production.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Estimates based on sources and methods described in "The Changing Wealth of Nations: Measuring Sustainable Development in the New Millennium" (World Bank, 2011).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total natural resources rents (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total natural resources rents are the sum of oil rents, natural gas rents, coal rents (hard and soft), mineral rents, and forest rents.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Estimates based on sources and methods described in "The Changing Wealth of Nations: Measuring Sustainable Development in the New Millennium" (World Bank, 2011).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross domestic savings, private (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Private sector’s gross domestic saving is derived as value added in private sector at factor cost less private consumption, etc. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross domestic savings, private (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Private sector’s gross domestic saving is derived as value added in private sector at factor cost less private consumption, etc. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross domestic savings, private (constant LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Private sector’s gross domestic saving is derived as value added in private sector at factor cost less private consumption, etc. Data are in constant local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross domestic savings, public (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Public sector’s gross domestic saving is derived as value added in public sector at factor cost plus all indirect taxes, net less general government consumption expenditure. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross domestic savings, public (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Public sector’s gross domestic saving is derived as value added in public sector at factor cost plus all indirect taxes, net less general government consumption expenditure. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross domestic savings, public (constant LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Public sector’s gross domestic saving is derived as value added in public sector at factor cost plus all indirect taxes, net less general government consumption expenditure. Data are in constant local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross domestic savings (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross domestic savings are calculated as GDP less final consumption expenditure (total consumption). Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross domestic savings (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross domestic savings are calculated as GDP less final consumption expenditure (total consumption). Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross domestic savings, total (constant 2000 US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross domestic savings are calculated as the difference between GDP and total consumption. Data are in constant 2000 U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross domestic savings (constant LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross domestic savings are calculated as GDP less final consumption expenditure (total consumption). Data are in constant local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross domestic savings (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross domestic savings are calculated as GDP less final consumption expenditure (total consumption).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross domestic income (constant 2005 US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross domestic income is derived as the sum of GDP and the terms of trade adjustment. Data are in constant 2005 U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross domestic income (constant LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross domestic income is derived as the sum of GDP and the terms of trade adjustment. Data are in constant local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GNI, Atlas method (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: GNI, Atlas method (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank

wb:indicator.wb:name: GNI (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: GNI (formerly GNP) is the sum of value added by all resident producers plus any product taxes (less subsidies) not included in the valuation of output plus net receipts of primary income (compensation of employees and property income) from abroad. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GNI (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: GNI (formerly GNP) is the sum of value added by all resident producers plus any product taxes (less subsidies) not included in the valuation of output plus net receipts of primary income (compensation of employees and property income) from abroad. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GNI (constant 2005 US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: GNI (formerly GNP) is the sum of value added by all resident producers plus any product taxes (less subsidies) not included in the valuation of output plus net receipts of primary income (compensation of employees and property income) from abroad. Data are in constant 2005 U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GNI growth (annual %)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: GNI (formerly GNP) is the sum of value added by all resident producers plus any product taxes (less subsidies) not included in the valuation of output plus net receipts of primary income (compensation of employees and property income) from abroad.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GNI (constant LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: GNI (formerly GNP) is the sum of value added by all resident producers plus any product taxes (less subsidies) not included in the valuation of output plus net receipts of primary income (compensation of employees and property income) from abroad. Data are in constant local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GNI, PPP (current international $)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: PPP GNI (formerly PPP GNP) is gross national income (GNI) converted to international dollars using purchasing power parity rates. An international dollar has the same purchasing power over GNI as a U.S. dollar has in the United States. Gross national income is the sum of value added by all resident producers plus any product taxes (less subsidies) not included in the valuation of output plus net receipts of primary income (compensation of employees and property income) from abroad. Data are in current international dollars. For most economies PPP figures are extrapolated from the 2011 International Comparison Program (ICP) benchmark estimates or imputed using a statistical model based on the 2011 ICP. For 47 high- and upper middle-income economies conversion factors are provided by Eurostat and the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, International Comparison Program database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GNI, PPP (constant 2011 international $)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: PPP GNI (formerly PPP GNP) is gross national income (GNI) converted to international dollars using purchasing power parity rates. An international dollar has the same purchasing power over GNI as a U.S. dollar has in the United States. Gross national income is the sum of value added by all resident producers plus any product taxes (less subsidies) not included in the valuation of output plus net receipts of primary income (compensation of employees and property income) from abroad. Data are in constant 2011 international dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, International Comparison Program database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GNI per capita, Atlas method (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: GNI per capita (formerly GNP per capita) is the gross national income, converted to U.S. dollars using the World Bank Atlas method, divided by the midyear population. GNI is the sum of value added by all resident producers plus any product taxes (less subsidies) not included in the valuation of output plus net receipts of primary income (compensation of employees and property income) from abroad. GNI, calculated in national currency, is usually converted to U.S. dollars at official exchange rates for comparisons across economies, although an alternative rate is used when the official exchange rate is judged to diverge by an exceptionally large margin from the rate actually applied in international transactions. To smooth fluctuations in prices and exchange rates, a special Atlas method of conversion is used by the World Bank. This applies a conversion factor that averages the exchange rate for a given year and the two preceding years, adjusted for differences in rates of inflation between the country, and through 2000, the G-5 countries (France, Germany, Japan, the United Kingdom, and the United States). From 2001, these countries include the Euro area, Japan, the United Kingdom, and the United States.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GNI per capita (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: GNI per capita is gross national income divided by midyear population. GNI (formerly GNP) is the sum of value added by all resident producers plus any product taxes (less subsidies) not included in the valuation of output plus net receipts of primary income (compensation of employees and property income) from abroad. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GNI per capita (constant 2005 US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: GNI per capita is gross national income divided by midyear population. GNI (formerly GNP) is the sum of value added by all resident producers plus any product taxes (less subsidies) not included in the valuation of output plus net receipts of primary income (compensation of employees and property income) from abroad. Data are in constant 2005 U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GNI per capita growth (annual %)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Annual percentage growth rate of GNI per capita based on constant local currency. Aggregates are based on constant 2005 U.S. dollars. GNI per capita is gross national income divided by midyear population. GNI (formerly GNP) is the sum of value added by all resident producers plus any product taxes (less subsidies) not included in the valuation of output plus net receipts of primary income (compensation of employees and property income) from abroad.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GNI per capita (constant LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: GNI per capita is gross national income divided by midyear population. GNI (formerly GNP) is the sum of value added by all resident producers plus any product taxes (less subsidies) not included in the valuation of output plus net receipts of primary income (compensation of employees and property income) from abroad. Data are in constant local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GNI per capita, PPP (current international $)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: GNI per capita based on purchasing power parity (PPP). PPP GNI is gross national income (GNI) converted to international dollars using purchasing power parity rates. An international dollar has the same purchasing power over GNI as a U.S. dollar has in the United States. GNI is the sum of value added by all resident producers plus any product taxes (less subsidies) not included in the valuation of output plus net receipts of primary income (compensation of employees and property income) from abroad. Data are in current international dollars based on the 2011 ICP round.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, International Comparison Program database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GNI per capita, PPP (constant 2011 international $)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: GNI per capita based on purchasing power parity (PPP). PPP GNI is gross national income (GNI) converted to international dollars using purchasing power parity rates. An international dollar has the same purchasing power over GNI as a U.S. dollar has in the United States. GNI is the sum of value added by all resident producers plus any product taxes (less subsidies) not included in the valuation of output plus net receipts of primary income (compensation of employees and property income) from abroad. Data are in constant 2011 international dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, International Comparison Program database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross savings (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross savings are calculated as gross national income less total consumption, plus net transfers. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross savings (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross savings are calculated as gross national income less total consumption, plus net transfers. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross savings (% of GNI)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross savings are calculated as gross national income less total consumption, plus net transfers.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross national savings, including net current transfers (constant 2000 US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross national savings including net current transfers is equal to gross domestic savings plus net income and net current transfers from abroad. Data are in constant 2000 U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross national savings, including net current transfers (constant LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross national savings, including net current transfers is equal to gross domestic savings plus net income and net current transfers from abroad. Data are in constant local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: "World Bank country economists. "

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross savings (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross savings are calculated as gross national income less total consumption, plus net transfers.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross national savings, private (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross saving real in private sector is derived as gross disposable income REAL in private sector less private consumption expenditure. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross national savings, private (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross saving real in private sector is derived as gross disposable income REAL in private sector less private consumption expenditure. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross national savings, private (constant LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross saving real in private sector is derived as gross disposable income REAL in private sector less private consumption expenditure. Data are in constant local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross national savings, public (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross saving in public sector is derived as gross disposable income in public sector less government final consumption expenditure. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross national savings, public (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross saving in public sector is derived as gross disposable income in public sector less government final consumption expenditure. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross national savings, public (constant LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross saving in public sector is derived as gross disposable income in public sector less government final consumption expenditure. Data are in constant local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross national disposable income (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross national income is derived as the sum of GNP and the terms of trade adjustment. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross national income (constant 2000 US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross national income is derived as the sum of GNP and the terms of trade adjustment. Data are in constant 2000 U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross national income (constant LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross national income is derived as the sum of GNP and the terms of trade adjustment. Data are in constant local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net income from abroad (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net income includes the net labor income and net property and entrepreneurial income components of the SNA. Labor income covers compensation of employees paid to nonresident workers. Property and entrepreneurial income covers investment income from the ownership of foreign financial claims (interest, dividends, rent, etc.) and nonfinancial property income (patents, copyrights, etc.). Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net income from abroad (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net income includes the net labor income and net property and entrepreneurial income components of the SNA. Labor income covers compensation of employees paid to nonresident workers. Property and entrepreneurial income covers investment income from the ownership of foreign financial claims (interest, dividends, rent, etc.) and nonfinancial property income (patents, copyrights, etc.). Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net income from abroad (constant LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net income includes the net labor income and net property and entrepreneurial income components of the SNA. Labor income covers compensation of employees paid to nonresident workers. Property and entrepreneurial income covers investment income from the ownership of foreign financial claims (interest, dividends, rent, etc.) and nonfinancial property income (patents, copyrights, etc.). Data are in constant local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Indirect taxes (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Taxes are compulsory, unrequited payments made by institutional units to government units. Indirect taxes consists of ‘taxes on products’ payable on goods and services when they are produced, delivered, sold, transferred or otherwise disposed by their producers, plus ‘other taxes on production’. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Indirect taxes (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Taxes are compulsory, unrequited payments made by institutional units to government units. Indirect taxes consists of ‘taxes on products’ payable on goods and services when they are produced, delivered, sold, transferred or otherwise disposed by their producers, plus ‘other taxes on production’. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net taxes on products (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net taxes on products (net indirect taxes) are the sum of product taxes less subsidies. Product taxes are those taxes payable by producers that relate to the production, sale, purchase or use of the goods and services. Subsidies are grants on the current account made by general government to private enterprises and unincorporated public enterprises. The grants may take the form of payments to ensure a guaranteed price or to enable maintenance of prices of goods and services below costs of production, and other forms of assistance to producers. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net taxes on products (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net taxes on products (net indirect taxes) are the sum of product taxes less subsidies. Product taxes are those taxes payable by producers that relate to the production, sale, purchase or use of the goods and services. Subsidies are grants on the current account made by general government to private enterprises and unincorporated public enterprises. The grants may take the form of payments to ensure a guaranteed price or to enable maintenance of prices of goods and services below costs of production, and other forms of assistance to producers. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net taxes on products (constant LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net taxes on products (net indirect taxes) are the sum of product taxes less subsidies. Product taxes are those taxes payable by producers that relate to the production, sale, purchase or use of the goods and services. Subsidies are grants on the current account made by general government to private enterprises and unincorporated public enterprises. The grants may take the form of payments to ensure a guaranteed price or to enable maintenance of prices of goods and services below costs of production, and other forms of assistance to producers. Data are in constant local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Subsidies (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Subsidies are current unrequited payments that government units make to enterprises, resident producers and importers. Subsidies may be designed to influence enterprises level or type of production, or the prices at which the products are sold. (Capital grants are in the national accounts classified as capital transfers.) Subsidies consists of ‘subsidies on products’, subsidies payable per unit of a good or a service, and ‘other subsidies on production’, which cover all other subsidies enterprises receives as a consequence of engaging in production. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Subsidies (current LCU; from SNA)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Subsidies are current unrequited payments that government units make to enterprises, resident producers and importers. Subsidies may be designed to influence enterprises level or type of production, or the prices at which the products are sold. (Capital grants are in the national accounts classified as capital transfers.) Subsidies consists of ‘subsidies on products’, subsidies payable per unit of a good or a service, and ‘other subsidies on production’, which cover all other subsidies enterprises receives as a consequence of engaging in production. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net current transfers from abroad (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Current transfers comprise transfers of income between residents of the reporting country and the rest of the world that carry no provisions for repayment. Net current transfers from abroad is equal to the unrequited transfers of income from nonresidents to residents minus the unrequited transfers from residents to nonresidents. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net current transfers from abroad (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Current transfers comprise transfers of income between residents of the reporting country and the rest of the world that carry no provisions for repayment. Net current transfers from abroad is equal to the unrequited transfers of income from nonresidents to residents minus the unrequited transfers from residents to nonresidents. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net current transfers from abroad (constant LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Current transfers comprise transfers of income between residents of the reporting country and the rest of the world that carry no provisions for repayment. Net current transfers from abroad is equal to the unrequited transfers of income from nonresidents to residents minus the unrequited transfers from residents to nonresidents. Data are in constant local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Terms of trade adjustment (constant LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The terms of trade effect equals capacity to import less exports of goods and services in constant prices. Data are in constant local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GDP Discrepancy, current US$, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: A statistical discrepancy usually arises when the GDP components are estimated independently by industrial origin and by expenditure categories. This item represents the discrepancy in the use of resources (i.e., the estimate of GDP by expenditure categories). Data are in current US$ millions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GDP Discrepancy, current LCU, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: A statistical discrepancy usually arises when the GDP components are estimated independently by industrial origin and by expenditure categories. This item represents the discrepancy in the use of resources (i.e., the estimate of GDP by expenditure categories). Data are in current LCU millions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GDP Discrepancy, constant US$, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: A statistical discrepancy usually arises when the GDP components are estimated independently by industrial origin and by expenditure categories. This item represents the discrepancy in the use of resources (i.e., the estimate of GDP by expenditure categories). Data are in constant US$ millions. The base year is 2005.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GDP Discrepancy, constant LCU, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: A statistical discrepancy usually arises when the GDP components are estimated independently by industrial origin and by expenditure categories. This item represents the discrepancy in the use of resources (i.e., the estimate of GDP by expenditure categories). Data are in constant LCU millions. The base year varies by country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GDP Discrepancy deflator, LCU
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The GDP Discrepancy implicit deflator is the ratio of GDP Discrepancy in current local currency to GDP Discrepancy in constant local currency. The base year varies by country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Output gap, %
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The output gap is calculated as actual GDP less potential GDP as a percent of potential GDP. Potential GDP is the estimated level of total output when the economy is operating at natural rate of unemployment. Estimates of output gaps are subject to a significant margin of uncertainty.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GDP, current US$, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: GDP at purchaser's prices is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in current US$ millions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GDP, current LCU, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: GDP at purchaser's prices is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in current LCU millions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GDP, PPP basis, current intl $, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: PPP GDP is gross domestic product converted to international dollars using purchasing power parity rates. An international dollar has the same purchasing power over GDP as the U.S. dollar has in the United States. GDP is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in current international dollar millions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GDP, constant US$, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: GDP at purchaser's prices is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in constant US$ millions. The base year is 2005.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Annual percentage growth rate of GDP at market prices based on constant 2010 US Dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: GDP is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: The World Bank

wb:indicator.wb:name: GDP, constant LCU, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: GDP at purchaser's prices is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in constant LCU millions. The base year varies by country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GDP, PPP basis, constant intl $, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: PPP GDP is gross domestic product converted to international dollars using purchasing power parity rates. An international dollar has the same purchasing power over GDP as the U.S. dollar has in the United States. GDP is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in constant 2005 international dollar millions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GDP deflator, LCU
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The GDP implicit deflator is the ratio of GDP in current local currency to GDP in constant local currency. The base year varies by country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GDP, PPP basis, deflator
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The PPP Based GDP implicit deflator is the ratio of PPP Based GDP in current currency to PPP Based GDP in constant currency. The base year is 2005.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GDP Potential, constant US$, millions
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Potential GDP is the estimated level of total output when the economy is operating at natural rate of unemployment, presented in constant US$, millions. The base year is 2005.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Estimated Potential GDP (real local currency units, various base years)
Countries categorized as offshore financial centers by the IMF and the Financial Stability Forum (FSF)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Countries categorized as offshore financial centers by the IMF and the Financial Stability Forum (FSF).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Oranges, $/mt, current$
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Oranges (Mediterranean exporters) navel, EEC indicative import price, c.i.f. Paris
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: INTERFEL, Fel Actualite hebdo; FRuiTrop; Marche Europeens Des Fruits et Legumes; World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: DEC alternative conversion factor (LCU per US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The DEC alternative conversion factor is the underlying annual exchange rate used for the World Bank Atlas method. As a rule, it is the official exchange rate reported in the IMF's International Financial Statistics (line rf). Exceptions arise where further refinements are made by World Bank staff. It is expressed in local currency units per U.S. dollar.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics, supplemented by World Bank staff estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Official exchange rate (LCU per US$, period average)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Official exchange rate refers to the exchange rate determined by national authorities or to the rate determined in the legally sanctioned exchange market. It is calculated as an annual average based on monthly averages (local currency units relative to the U.S. dollar).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics.

wb:indicator.wb:name: PPP conversion factor, GDP (LCU per international $)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Purchasing power parity conversion factor is the number of units of a country's currency required to buy the same amounts of goods and services in the domestic market as U.S. dollar would buy in the United States. This conversion factor is for GDP. For most economies PPP figures are extrapolated from the 2011 International Comparison Program (ICP) benchmark estimates or imputed using a statistical model based on the 2011 ICP. For 47 high- and upper middle-income economies conversion factors are provided by Eurostat and the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, International Comparison Program database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: 2005 PPP conversion factor, GDP (LCU per international $)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Purchasing power parity conversion factor is the number of units of a country's currency required to buy the same amounts of goods and services in the domestic market as U.S. dollar would buy in the United States. This conversion factor is for GDP. Historical estimates are provided for the 2005 benchmark year only. A separate series is available for extrapolated estimates based on the latest ICP round.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, International Comparison Program database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Price level ratio of PPP conversion factor (GDP) to market exchange rate
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Purchasing power parity conversion factor is the number of units of a country's currency required to buy the same amount of goods and services in the domestic market as a U.S. dollar would buy in the United States. The ratio of PPP conversion factor to market exchange rate is the result obtained by dividing the PPP conversion factor by the market exchange rate. The ratio, also referred to as the national price level, makes it possible to compare the cost of the bundle of goods that make up gross domestic product (GDP) across countries. It tells how many dollars are needed to buy a dollar's worth of goods in the country as compared to the United States. PPP conversion factors are based on the 2011 ICP round.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, International Comparison Program database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: PPP conversion factor, private consumption (LCU per international $)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Purchasing power parity conversion factor is the number of units of a country's currency required to buy the same amounts of goods and services in the domestic market as U.S. dollar would buy in the United States. This conversion factor is for private consumption (i.e., household final consumption expenditure). For most economies PPP figures are extrapolated from the 2011 International Comparison Program (ICP) benchmark estimates or imputed using a statistical model based on the 2011 ICP. For 47 high- and upper middle-income economies conversion factors are provided by Eurostat and the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, International Comparison Program database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: 2005 PPP conversion factor, private consumption (LCU per international $)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Purchasing power parity conversion factor is the number of units of a country's currency required to buy the same amounts of goods and services in the domestic market as U.S. dollar would buy in the United States. This conversion factor is for private consumption (i.e., household final consumption expenditure). Historical estimates are provided for the 2005 benchmark year only. A separate series is available for extrapolated estimates based on the latest ICP round.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, International Comparison Program database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Palm oil, $/mt, current$
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Palm oil (Malaysia), 5% bulk, c.i.f. N. W. Europe
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: ISTA Mielke GmbH, Oil World; US Department of Agriculture; World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: DEC exchange rate (LCU per US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Exchange rate refers to the exchange rate determined by the Development Economics Group through the Atlas Method, which is an alternative rate used to smooth fluctuations in prices and exchange rates by a special method of conversion used by the World Bank. This applies a conversion factor that averages the exchange rate for a given year and the two preceding years, adjusted for differences in rates of inflation between the country, and through 2000, the G-5 countries (France, Germany, Japan, the United Kingdom, and the United States). From 2001, these countries include the Euro area, Japan, the United Kingdom, and the United States.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on World Development Indicators data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Official exchange rate (LCU per US$, end period)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Official exchange rate refers to the exchange rate determined by national authorities or to the rate determined in the legally sanctioned exchange market. This series shows the end period value of local currency units relative to the U.S. dollar.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics.
